Well, on top of what others have suggested about Rotterdam being one of the larger trade hubs in Europe it's also because growing crops is really a thing in the Netherlands. They do grow a lot of crop. Really. They do. It's a nation well suited for growing things. Easy access to water, and pretty flat ground with mostly healthy soil. A substantial lot of the greenhouse-growable crop that is consumed in Europe is originating from the Netherlands. It's not only traded there, but it is by tradition grown there. It's pretty obvious that the best way to access a market is to go to the place where most of the trade would have happened anyway, so that is what both buyers and sellers do. And as a result, they inflate the importance of the market there. You can grow peppers outdoors in parts of Europe, but you can also grow them in a greenhouse in the Netherlands. And if you grow them in a greenhouse, you can control the growing environment in a way that makes it possible to harvest some volume every day. all year around. If you want to up the volume, all you need is to up the amount of plants and the volume will follow. Most crops that grow outdoors get two or three harvests a year, there is no way a natural growth can compete with greenhouse growth that outputs every day. It's for practical purposes the same product. One producer sells every day, with a very predicted volume. The other sells twice a year with a high-risk, weather-conditioned volume. It's not really hard to predict who is gonna sell more and if I'm to guess who has the closest relation with the market I'm gonna guess it's the greenhouse owner who talks to his buyers every day.,URL0 Summary: they export high-value products, and many of these are actually grown elsewhere and just traded through the Netherlands.','The largest and most important port in Europe is Rotterdam in the Netherlands. Agricultural products come from all over the continent to the Netherlands be exported.

Anthony Tavernor has been restoring Plas Cadnant Hidden Gardens, near Menai Bridge, on Anglesey for 20 years, describing it as his life's project. But after days of heavy rain, a section of his project has been inundated. He said: "The last few days of heavy rain have put a lot of water in the beds and the house. "I've never had it flood before but I've never had it flood in that amount of time. "We've had a lot of water in the beds and in the house. It's the first time I've seen that." Mr Tavernor, who works at the National Trust's Snowdonia office in Bangor, said the flooded gardens would be dug out and replanted, adding: "It's been a good few years and we've been doing really well but we're starting to struggle now. "It's not a total loss but it's a big job to get it all out and replant it. "It's the first time we've had it flood in that amount of time. "I've been working at the National Trust for 30 years and this is the first time I've had it flood in that amount of time. "I've never had it flood in that amount of time." Mr Tavernor said his wife and two daughters were also affected by the flooding. He added: "It's really sad. I was just getting it to a point where it was coming on. "I was really hoping to finish this year but I'm going to be 60 in October and I'm not going to be able to finish it." Mr Tavernor said his wife was also affected by the flooding and had to spend the night in a hotel. The family has since been staying at a cottage near Conwy. He said: "We had to stay in a hotel in Conwy overnight because we couldn't get in. "It was the worst flood I've ever seen. It's the first time I've ever had it flood in that amount of time."

In Edith Wharton's novel "The House of Mirth," published in 1905, the author delves into the complexities of social hierarchy and class distinctions that permeated American society during the Gilded Age. Through her portrayal of the main character, Lily Bart, Wharton vividly illustrates how rigid societal expectations and economic disparity contribute to the perpetuation of social inequality. This paper will explore these themes in depth, examining how they shape the characters' actions and motivations throughout the narrative.
One of the most striking aspects of "The House of Mirth" is its depiction of the insular world of New York City's upper-class society. This exclusive circle is governed by strict rules and conventions, which dictate everything from acceptable modes of dress and behavior to suitable marriage partners. Lily Bart, born into this privileged sphere, finds herself at odds with its values and constraints. As an unmarried woman without independent means, she is acutely aware of her precarious position within the social order. Her struggle to maintain her status while navigating the treacherous waters of courtship and financial survival serves as a microcosm for the broader issues of social mobility and gender roles that are central to the novel's thematic concerns.
Wharton's portrayal of the male characters in "The House of Mirth" further underscores the importance of wealth and status in determining one's place within the social hierarchy. For example, Lawrence Selden, who comes from a respectable but not particularly affluent family, is initially viewed as a suitable match for Lily due to his education and gentlemanly demeanor. However, as their relationship progresses, it becomes clear that their differing economic circumstances pose a significant obstacle to any potential union. Similarly, the wealthy and powerful Simon Rosedale represents both the allure and danger of upward mobility. Despite his vast fortune, he remains an outsider among the old money crowd, whose acceptance he craves yet never fully achieves.
In contrast to the men in her life, Lily's female contemporaries serve as cautionary tales about the consequences of defying societal norms. Her friend Grace Stepney, for instance, has fallen on hard times after divorcing her husband, while the enigmatic Bertha Dorset embodies the corrupting influence of wealth and power. These women highlight the limited options available to those who challenge the established order, reinforcing the notion that conformity is essential for survival within the oppressive structure of the class system.

We do a Probabilistic Analysis of the Network generated by robots involved inStochastic Boundary Coverage. In this paper we introduce a new type of path in the domain, that we call the H-path, which is more general than the classical H-path. We provide an algorithm for finding the H-path that we believe is the first algorithm for finding the H-path that runs in time polynomial in the size of the input. We then present an algorithm for finding the shortest path to a point in the domain that we believe is the first algorithm for finding the shortest path to a point in the domain that runs in time polynomial in the size of the input. We finally give an algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain that we believe is the first algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain that runs in time polynomial in the size of the input. The complexity of the algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain depends on the nature of the domain. We believe that the algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain that we propose is the first algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain that is polynomial in the size of the input and in the degree of the domains. We also show that there is no algorithm for finding the shortest path in a domain in time polynomial in the size of the input and in the degree of the domains.'

Imagine it's minutes away from the school having summer break, then all of a sudden the teacher hands out the summer project packet the class is assigned to do during summer. Others think it'll be a horrible assignment because the teacher is creating the requirements. If students really pay attention to what's happening they'll realize the teacher is making the class do less work compared to what students wanted. Summer projects should be teacher designed because they have more experience, they'll make sure the class covers new material, and it'll be easier for teachers to grade.

Teachers know what results they want when it comes down to projects. They've went to college, learned about designing projects, and spent their time and money on being taught how to grade and make assignments. The school faculty know our strengths and weaknesses, what we need and what we don't, teachers have walked in our shoes. They know what students want before the students know.

The schools number one priority is to teach and make students learn new information. Teachers know how to introduce new topics, ideas, and questions that'll force students to use their brain. They're aware of what children know and don't know. Teachers know that it would take too long for students to make their assignment because they haven't been taught how to grade or make a rubric to grade with.

Having the teachers design the project will be easier for them to grade. They know what they want to look for in the assignment. Teachers teach, make assignments, and grade for a living, and they know what to expect. The school faculty know what we'll achieve and what we'll fail at, they making rubrics and grading systems designed for students.

However, students would have fun inventing their own requirements for the assignment, but students just use what they already know. Teachers will make sure others learn because that's their job. They'll have students focus on the project, and not creating it.

In conclusion, having the teacher design the classes summer project makes it easier for you and your teacher. Students shoud learn and focus on their work while teachers should make the work and focus on what the students need to learn. Teachers have more knowledge when it comes to grading, they'll make sure students contain new information, and they grade better when they use their own rubic.

Contrary to a lot of Yelper's reviews, I wasn't that impressed with Blue Dust. It's a hole in the wall with a fantastic beer selection. It's off the beaten path of the waterfront, located across the tracks towards Eighth Ave. next to a tattoo parlor on Amity Street. I'd heard a lot about this place as well as read just about every review on Yelp and newspaper reviews. I wasn't sure what to expect, but a dark, dank, Burgh bar wasn't it. I was highly impressed with the bar, any brand of vodka, flavored, proof, etc, bacon bourbon, and a nice selection of beers. I had a black IPA, which was awesome with the Spicy China Doll (a thick pasty bean dip that could have used a bit of salt) served with very good tortilla chips that's weren't a bit greasy. For Dinner I had a portobello wrap, it was nice and meaty but lacked basic salt and pepper seasoning. Neither the app or wrap really stood out in my mind. If this was the last restaurant on earth, I'd come back, by then maybe they'll know how to properly season food before being consumed by their customers.

Dear Principal,

I believe that requiring students to perform community service is a great idea. Helping the community is a valuable experience that can teach us important life skills and values. Many of my friends have already been participating in community service activities, such as tutoring elementary school children and cleaning up litter. They have found that it not only benefits the community, but also helps them develop a sense of responsibility and compassion.

Requiring community service would also encourage students to get involved in issues that affect their communities. For example, students could participate in environmental projects, such as cleaning up local parks or waterways. This not only helps the environment, but also raises awareness about the importance of protecting our natural resources.

Additionally, community service can help students develop important skills that will benefit them in the future. For example, tutoring children can help students develop their communication and leadership skills, while cleaning up litter can teach them about the importance of taking initiative and being responsible for their community.

Some of my friends may argue that community service takes too much time away from what they need or want to do. However, I believe that the benefits of community service far outweigh any perceived drawbacks. Not only does it help the community, but it also provides students with valuable experiences and skills that will benefit them in the long run.

Furthermore, requiring community service would send a positive message to the community. It would show that our school values civic engagement and is committed to making a positive impact. This can help build stronger relationships between our school and the community, and encourage others to get involved in community service as well.

In conclusion, I strongly believe that requiring students to perform community service is a great idea. It would not only benefit the community, but also provide students with valuable experiences and skills. I urge you to consider implementing a community service requirement for all students.

Sincerely,

Music therapy is a type of psychotherapy that uses music to improve a person's mental health. It can be used to help people with a variety of mental health conditions, including depression, anxiety, stress, and trauma. Music therapy can also be used to help people with physical health conditions, such as chronic pain and cancer.

There are many different ways that music therapy can be used. Some common methods include:

- Listening to music: This can help to relax the body and mind, and can also help to improve mood.
- Singing: This can help to express emotions, and can also help to improve vocal skills and confidence.
- Playing an instrument: This can help to develop motor skills and coordination, and can also help to improve self-expression.
- Composing music: This can help to express emotions and creativity, and can also help to improve problem-solving skills.

Music therapy can be a very effective treatment for a variety of mental health conditions. It is a safe and non-invasive therapy that can be used with people of all ages. If you are interested in learning more about music therapy, please talk to your doctor or mental health professional.

Here are some of the benefits of music therapy:

- It can help to reduce stress and anxiety.
- It can help to improve mood.
- It can help to promote relaxation.
- It can help to improve self-expression.
- It can help to develop coping skills.
- It can help to improve social skills.
- It can help to improve cognitive functioning.
- It can help to reduce pain.
- It can help to improve sleep.

Music therapy is a powerful tool that can be used to improve mental health. If you are struggling with a mental health condition, please talk to your doctor or mental health professional about whether music therapy may be right for you.

Dear State Senator,

I am writing to express my opinion on the matter of the Electoral College and whether it should be abolished in favor of electing the president by popular vote. As a 9th grade student, I have been studying the history and function of the Electoral College and have come to the conclusion that it is time for a change.

The Electoral College was established over 200 years ago as a compromise between those who wanted Congress to choose the president and those who wanted the people to elect him directly. However, the system has faced criticism for its potential to cause confusion and for not always reflecting the popular vote, as seen in the 2000 election. Critics argue that it is outdated, unfair, and can lead to disasters like faithless electors or a tie in electoral votes, which would throw the election to Congress.

One of the main arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it protects state interests and federalism. However, this defense is increasingly seen as inadequate. The system's origins, tied to concessions to slaveholders and assumptions about public information access, are no longer relevant. In today's society, information is readily available to the public and state interests can be represented in other ways.

On the other hand, direct elections would be a more equitable and straightforward method of electing the president. It would reflect the popular will more accurately and avoid the possibility of a candidate winning the presidency without receiving the most votes. This system would also eliminate the possibility of faithless electors and ties in electoral votes, which could lead to a political crisis.

Some argue that direct elections could lead to recounts and controversies, but these can be avoided with proper voting systems and regulations. Additionally, the concern about third-party candidates is not a valid reason to keep the Electoral College, as they can still participate in direct elections.

In conclusion, the Electoral College is an outdated system that no longer serves its intended purpose. It is time for a change to a more equitable and straightforward method of electing the president, such as direct elections by popular vote. I urge you to consider the abolition of the Electoral College and the implementation of direct elections for the presidency.

Sincerely,

The given flow chart demostrates the effects of deforestation on nature. These influences can occur through four possible routes.
First, one of the initial impacts of such activity is when heavy logging instruments compress the soil, making it hard and baked. Thus, rain water may run off and eventually resulting in flooding. Secondly, with clear cutting of forests, there is a decrease in roots that hold the top soil in it. This will lead to soil erosion.
Moreover, deforestaion is belived to rise the likelihood of burning, either delibrately or accidentally. As waste food from logging is destroyed, some micro-organisms that feed on it might vanish. Other species get in the field, causing a degradation of vegetation. This could be also a result of soil erosion or an increase of drought. All of these events are responsible for less biodiversity. Finally, a decrease in plants means less moisture to air, less precipitation and more exacerbation of drought.
Overall, as is shown by this chart, the deforestation process has substantial repersussions on nature through various ways. Unless any decrease of this detrimental activity, nature would witness flooding, soil erosions, less biodiversity and severe drought.

Human Factor in Manufacturing Operations Essay

Introduction

The human factor has always been one of the issues significantly impacting the manufacturing process and preconditioning a critical deterioration in the quality of final products. For this reason, there are numerous attempts to minimize the negative impact of this factor and achieve better results. The article suggested for the discussion also revolves around the same issue. The fact is that the garment industry becomes especially vulnerable to the pernicious impact of this factor (Day, 2016).

If workers do not have the needed skills or make mistakes some pieces of clothes will be spoiled. The authors suggest one of the possible solutions, which implies additional training for employees to improve their skills and ensure the absence of critical mistakes. The given option can be considered efficient enough as multiple research works show that the explanation of innovative ways to perform essential activities demonstrates appropriate results (Montagna, 2015). For this reason, it can be applied in different conditions.

Discussion

Additionally, the authors assume that the explanation of quality’s significance to workers is a good way to attain better results. However, the suggested quality awareness program can be supported by the introduction of innovative tools to monitor the manufacturing process and admit mistakes preconditioned by the human factor at the early stages (Wright, 2017). It will help to reduce the number of spoiled things and preserve the high quality of garments produced by various companies.

In such a way, the problem of the human factor and its critical importance for all spheres becomes evident, and demands increased attention. One of the solutions presupposes the use of additional training along with the focus on increased workers awareness to ensure that they understand the importance of their contribution to the companys rise.

References

Day, W. (2016). Design error: A human factors approach . New York, NY: CRC Press.

Montagna, G. (2015). Multi-dimensional consumers: Fashion and human factors. Procedia Manufacturing, 3 , 6550-6556.

Wright, I. (2017). H uman error is worse in manufacturing compared to other sectors . Web.

Once upon a time, in a faraway land, there lived a young girl named Laura. Laura was a curious girl who loved to explore and discover new things. One day, while wandering through the forest, she stumbled upon an old, abandoned cottage. The cottage was overgrown with weeds and vines, and the door was partly open. Laura was curious about what was inside, so she pushed open the door and stepped inside.
To her surprise, the cottage was filled with all sorts of treasures. There were old books, dusty bottles, and antique furniture. Laura was fascinated by everything she saw, and she spent hours exploring the cottage. She found a dusty old journal on a shelf, and she decided to take it with her. As she flipped through the pages, she realized that the journal belonged to a famous explorer who had once lived in the cottage.
As Laura continued to explore the cottage, she discovered a hidden room in the attic. The room was filled with old maps and charts, and Laura realized that the explorer had been searching for a lost treasure. She was determined to find the treasure herself, and she spent the next few weeks studying the maps and charts.
Finally, Laura decided that she was ready to embark on her journey. She packed her bags, said goodbye to her family, and set out on her adventure. She traveled to distant lands, faced danger and adversity, and finally, after many months of searching, she found the lost treasure.
Laura returned home a hero, and she was celebrated by her family and friends. She had proven that she was brave and determined, and she had discovered a passion for exploration that would last a lifetime.

This place never disappoints. I have never had a bad meal here. There are always plenty of vegetarian selections to choose from. I recommend making a reservation as they are usually booked very early in the day and can get quite busy later on in the week but you will be able to find something suitable. I went with family for dinner last night, it was more than I thought it would be at 20.00 per person. The food was good and my husband enjoyed his main course but I didn't think there were enough sides. Our server said he used to work at this restaurant so he knew what we wanted but unfortunately couldn't help us. It really was only two courses that needed ordering (my son liked his pizza) so we should have asked for more. We also felt left out because our order wasn't taken up until later in the evening when some other people came in for their meals. Overall, not too shabby though. We ordered the beef tenderloin which was delicious! My mom loved her garlic fries too! Over all I give it a 5 star rating!! Excellent restaurant - great service, very clean and great quality food. Don't expect much since it is an Indian joint but they do make wonderful curries. Pad Thai should be a staple dish in any Indian restaurant. They offer biryanis as well. Also worth noting: continental breakfast is extremely affordable (8). One tip: don't go for lunch unless you like the idea of being hungry most of the time. The buffets they serve are pretty large but they charge 5 extra per plate. If you prefer to eat healthier, I highly suggest coffee or tea instead (no milk please!) Love going here to eat. The best thing about this place is how the food tastes. Their salads are humongous! I know the guy who runs their business has been doing this for 30 years now and no one ever complains - even though they probably pay him NOT to smile anymore! He will still squeeze your flowers if it helps sell the salad.

While the idea of cars driving themselves sounds like something out of a sci-fi movie, it's important to consider both the benefits and drawbacks of this emerging technology. After reading the article "Driverless Cars are Coming," I have come to the conclusion that the development of driverless cars is not the best solution for our current transportation needs.

One of the main limitations of driverless cars is their current technological limitations. The article states that these vehicles are not yet capable of handling complex driving scenarios at higher speeds. They are reliable for simple functions at speeds up to 25 mph, but beyond that, the technology falters. This raises questions about their practicality - if a driver still needs to be actively engaged, are these cars truly driverless? Moreover, the need for constant vigilance negates the supposed benefits of having driverless cars, such as increased productivity or relaxation during commutes.

Another significant concern is privacy. Manufacturers are considering installing cameras to monitor drivers, which raises serious privacy issues. Being constantly watched and evaluated by a manufacturer is unsettling, and could lead to increased stress and distracted driving. Traditional cars, without such surveillance, have generally performed well, questioning the necessity of this feature in driverless cars. This intrusive measure is not worth the supposed benefits, especially when there are other ways to ensure driver engagement, such as using sensors and alerts.

Furthermore, the economic implications of transitioning to driverless cars are substantial. The vehicles require compatible infrastructure, such as 'smart roads' that can communicate with them. The cost of upgrading our roads to accommodate these cars would be exorbitantly expensive, and it's unclear who would bear these costs. Additionally, the logistics and financial burden of making smart roads universally compatible with all types of vehicles is daunting. It's unrealistic to expect every road and vehicle to be compatible, making driverless cars a less practical solution.

In conclusion, while driverless cars represent a remarkable technological advancement, their current form leaves much to be desired. The focus should perhaps be on refining existing technologies rather than pushing for a futuristic ideal that doesn't yet align with practical, economic, or privacy-related concerns. Therefore, I argue against the development of driverless cars at this time. We should instead invest in improving our existing transportation systems and infrastructure to make them more efficient, environmentally friendly, and accessible to all. By doing so, we can create a more equitable and practical transportation system that benefits everyone, without sacrificing privacy and safety.

I can sense the effort that you placed into developing your response to the given discussion point. However, your inability to properly form English sentences have prevented you from creating an understandable essay. The message you are trying to deliver is not properly supported. The first line of reasoning does not make sense. The examiner will not understand what you mean by; "In the highly competitive edge , people need to possess various skills to stay competitive edge in the fierce society . " What do you mean by competitive edge? Does this refer to the profession of a person? The life of a person? It shows that you are not capable of forming understandable English sentences.  
  
Your ideas are not clearly represented in your writing so that means you have to work on developing your sentence formation / structuring skills. That is because you do not really know how to properly use English words. I believe that is because you are thinking in Vietnamese and then looking for possible translated words in English. When you do that, you end up making improper word choices which leads you to write improperly developed sentences.  
  
To be clear, you cannot discuss working benefits for knowing language, and then discuss it in terms of learning languages while traveling. If that is the case, then the office worker should be learning the language from his own country because he cannot leave his job for years, which is the amount of time that it will take him to learn the language if he chooses to travel to a country. There is a clear disconnection in your discussion development.  
  
This type of TOEFL writing cannot get you a score higher than 2. You need to improve your English vocabulary and do more sentence structuring exercises. Focus on the sentence development and the vocabulary should follow suit. If you can, enroll in English language classes first. Don't just jump into essay writing. You are capable of doing that yet. You need to have a teacher to help you improve for now.

SO YOU WANT TO BE A SEAGOING COWBOY

If you're reading this article, I'm guessing you want to be a Seagoing Cowboy. It's an interesting job. It doesn't require any special skills or years and years of experience. You just have to know how to take good care of animals and not get seasick easily. It's not that hard. Read on; I'll show you why.

There are a lot of great reasons to join the program. Here are some. When I was a Seagoing Cowboy,(Yes, I was!) along with helping other countries get back on their feet, I got to see awe-inspiring things, such as the Acropolis in Greece and the Panama Canal on my way to China. Taking care of the animals wasn't that hard. Sure you had to clean the poop-ridden stalls and carry up heavy bags of oats, but the animals made great company. On rides back home, you could relax and play games with the rest of the crew.

Being a Seagoing Cowboy could be dangerous, too. Once, after making my hourly report to the captain, I fell down a slippery ladder and almost went overboard and died! Luckily I got away with only a broken rib and more caution. People in the countries we aided could've been hostile. Seas could've been violent. Storms could've broken our ship to bite-size pieces. Fortunately, none of that happened;most of my trips were safe ones

When I was a Seagoing Cowboy, it opened up the world to me. I saw that the world wasn't all sunshine and rainbows, like the little me thought. The world was full of unfairness and was my job, everybody's job, to help stop it. I stepped up to do my part by joining the Seagoing Cowboys. Do your part. Join the Seagoing Cowboys program today. Make the world a better place, one cow at a time.

In many places in Switzerland, household rubbish disposal is charged for. Rubbish (except dangerous items, batteries etc.) is only collected if it is in bags which either have a payment sticker attached, or in official bags with the surcharge paid at the time of purchase. This gives a financial incentive to recycle as much as possible, since recycling is free. Illegal disposal of garbage is not tolerated but usually the enforcement of such laws is limited to violations that involve the unlawful disposal of larger volumes at traffic intersections and public areas. Fines for not paying the disposal fee range from CHF 200-500.

Netflix unveiled a virtual streamer this week as the host of a weekly show on the company's YouTube channel. N-ko Mei Kurono is a sheep-human lifeform. Virtual YouTubers (Vtubers) are becoming increasingly popular in Japan and other parts of Asia, and now Netflix is taking notice of this trend. These virtual streamers are essentially computer-created characters that are controlled by human presenters, and they allow for a new level of interaction between the presenter and their audience. With the rise of virtual reality and other advanced technologies, it's likely that we'll see more and more Vtubers in the future - and there's a good chance that Netflix won't be the only entertainment giant to jump on board.

They should also contact the authorities in order to determine if any laws have been broken. The Broncos took an early lead in Super Bowl 50 and never trailed. Newton was limited by Denver's defense, which sacked him seven times and forced him into three turnovers, and by a nagging injury to his throwing arm. Cam Newton has earned his share of criticism for his performance in Super Bowl 50, but the league's most valuable player has also received plenty of support in the days since. While Newton's post-game comments were brief and pessimistic, the 26-year-old quarterback has given a more optimistic outlook in recent days. "I'm a firm believer that things happen for a reason," Newton told reporters Wednesday. "I feel like there's some greater things in store for me in the future. Right now, it's like a tug of war between your mind and your heart. "Your mind is telling you one thing and your heart is saying another thing," Newton said. "I'm still trying to figure it out myself. I'm not one to be sulking or mad or anything like that. It is what it is." Newton was limited by Denver's defense, which sacked him seven times and forced him into three turnovers, and by a nagging injury to his throwing arm. Newton had surgery on his left shoulder in March, and he aggravated it in the second quarter of the Super Bowl. He injured his right shoulder on a sack during the third quarter, which prevented him from throwing a deep ball in the fourth quarter. "That was the most challenging part," Newton said. "I felt like we were on the verge of getting something going, and then when I tried to force it out there, I tried to do something that I shouldn't have been doing. It didn't go my way." Despite the performance, Newton said he has already moved past the loss. "I've already moved on," Newton said. "It's like, 'Man, it's already time to get ready for OTAs, time to get ready for spring ball.' I'm already trying to get ready for next year." Newton's Panthers teammate Roman Harper told CBS Sports that the Broncos' defense beat the Panthers, not Newton. "He didn't play well, but the Broncos' defense took it to us," Harper said. "They beat us up. You got to give them credit for that. You got to give them a lot of credit for that. I think our offensive line and Cam took the blame for that. "A lot of people thought Cam didn't play well because he had the fumble and the two interceptions, but we didn't get anything going on the ground. When you can't run the ball, it's hard to complete passes and make things happen."

is a green vehicle that says go green on it. The car drives by and I start to wonder if the driver is truly going green as he approaches me with my white van at 50mph. The drivers seem genuinely concerned about reducing their carbon footprint, but some are using these vehicles for purely practical reasons or simply because they have more money than sense! I've done an experiment in London over two weeks ago trying out how easy it's get from one part of town to another - usually taking a bus stop 15-20 minutes away! On average it took 11minutes 47seconds (averaged between two buses) so I've been getting pretty fast results here...but then again there's no time limit and I'm only stopping when necessarywanted which means I'm probably missing many stops along the way and therefore not being efficient... So what do you think? Is this all just marketing hype and the people driving electric cars aren't actually doing anything different? Members of the RMT union will walk out at 11:00 BST on 26 April and at the same time on 10 and 12 May. The union is against plans for the A406 route to become a segregated busway and fears the loss of jobs. RMT General Secretary Mick Cash said: "RMT members have consistently made it clear that they want to work with the company and the Government to reach a solution. "Instead, the Government is continuing with its plans to privatise the Highways Agency and abolish bus services along the A406. "This is not a dispute about whether we want to work or not. It is a dispute about whether the Government's privatisation plans will lead to the closure of services and the loss of jobs.

Texting & Driving

Recently, people have more and more smart phone. Not only do they have smart phones but more people drive. Texting while driving is proven to be dangerous and hazardous to you and others. With people texting and driving it creates more car accidents and even deaths. The cell phone is an attention grabber that causes deaths. In the US, the government has recently been putting laws on phones being used while driving. Around the world texting and driving should be stopped to prevent any car accidents and deaths.

When a car accident happens it's not always because the person who caused it simply hit the other person but was on their phone. It states that 38% of people ages 18-24 surveyed to see if they know their own state laws on texting and driving. Within those 38% only 55% said it was illegal to text and drive. 14% of car crashes that were fatal were caused by cellphones and in 2018 4,637 people were killed due to texting and driving. People that use their smartphones while driving have the urge to pick it up and answer the phone or reply to a text message. These few seconds could lead to an accident due to traffic flow or losing control of the car.

In 2016 3,450 fatalities were caused by drivers on their phones. Texting and driving is the leading cause of teen deaths, and about 3,000 teens die each year from texting and driving. In Minnesota a teenager was in the car with her boyfriend while texting and driving, she ran a red light and t-boned into a vehicle killing a father and a 10 year old daughter, it was stated in the news article that when her boyfriend attempted to redirect her and tell her to focus on the road she ignored him and even cussed at him. These are the ignorant acts that led to the death of a father, a child, and a family

Some people may say that it is necessary to keep a phone around while driving in case of emergencies. Although that may be true, you are still more likely to use your phone regardless if its an emergency or not. States have been putting laws on phone uses which comes with fines.

In conclusion, people should not be able to text and drive. They cause deaths and injuries in the world. Death causes people to be in depression making their lives harder. Texting and driving has proves to be dangerous for you and others around you.

Once upon a time, millions of years ago, life on Earth began to evolve and change. The major scientific theories about human evolution, migration, and paleoanthropology try to explain how our ancestors came to be, where they traveled, and what they were like.

The first major scientific theory is Darwinism, proposed by Charles Darwin in the 19th century. Darwin's theory of evolution states that species change over time, and the process of natural selection favors the survival of the fittest. According to this theory, human beings evolved from early primates through a series of gradual changes, adapting to their environments and competing for resources.

Another significant theory is the Out of Africa theory, which suggests that modern humans, Homo sapiens, originated in Africa and then migrated to other parts of the world. This theory is supported by many scientific discoveries, such as the genetic evidence that shows all humans share a common ancestor from Africa. The Out of Africa theory also explains that human migration occurred in waves, with the first wave moving from Africa to Europe and Asia, followed by a second wave that spread throughout the rest of the world.

A more recent theory is the Multiregional Evolution theory, which posits that Homo sapiens evolved in multiple regions of the world at the same time. This theory challenges the Out of Africa theory and suggests that human evolution took place in various regions, such as Africa, Europe, and Asia. Proponents of this theory argue that there is evidence of a long history of human interbreeding, making it difficult to trace a single origin for our species.

Paleoanthropology, the study of human ancestors and their evolution, has led to the discovery of numerous fossils and artifacts that provide insight into the lives of our early human relatives. These findings have helped scientists piece together a timeline of human evolution, from the early hominids like Australopithecus afarensis, who lived around 3.9 million years ago, to the more recent Homo sapiens.

One famous fossil, named Lucy, was discovered in 1974 in Ethiopia and is estimated to be around 3.2 million years old. Lucy's discovery provided evidence that early hominids walked upright, a crucial adaptation for our ancestors as they began to travel greater distances and use tools.

Another significant find is the Neanderthal, a close relative of Homo sapiens that lived in Europe and Asia from around 400,000 to 40,000 years ago. Despite previous beliefs that Neanderthals were less intelligent and inferior to Homo sapiens, recent research suggests that they were highly skilled toolmakers and might have even interbred with our ancestors.

Throughout history, our understanding of human evolution, migration, and paleoanthropology has evolved, much like the species itself. Scientists continue to study the fossil record and the genetics of modern humans to unravel the mysteries of our past. As our knowledge grows, so too does our appreciation for the incredible journey that led to the diverse and complex beings we are today.

Once upon a time, there was a young girl named Sarah who was struggling with depression and anxiety. She had been dealing with these issues for years, but nothing seemed to help. She tried antidepressants, therapy, and even changed her lifestyle, but nothing seemed to make a difference. Sarah's parents were worried about her and wanted to find a new way to help her cope with her mental health problems.

One day, Sarah's therapist suggested that she try art therapy. At first, Sarah was skeptical. She didn't consider herself an artist and didn't think that creating things would help with her mental health. However, she decided to give it a try.

Sarah's first art therapy session was nerve-wracking. She was given a blank canvas and a variety of art supplies. She didn't know where to start, but her therapist told her to just let her emotions guide her. So, she started doodling and drawing random shapes and lines.

After a while, Sarah began to relax. She started to focus on her drawing and found that she was actually enjoying herself. She didn't realize it at the time, but she was expressing her feelings through her art. She had never felt so relaxed and at peace with herself.

As Sarah continued with her art therapy sessions, she started to notice a change in herself. She felt less anxious and depressed. She started to enjoy little things in life that she had previously overlooked. Her art became more expressive and meaningful.

One day, Sarah created a beautiful painting of a sunset. The colors were bright and vibrant, and it made her feel happy just looking at it. She decided to give the painting to her parents as a gift. They were overjoyed to see their daughter's work and were amazed at how much it had improved.

Sarah's parents were so grateful for art therapy. They saw how it had helped their daughter and decided to encourage their friends whose children were dealing with mental health issues to try it as well. Art therapy became a popular option for many people, and it has since helped countless individuals cope with their mental health problems.

In conclusion, art therapy played a significant role in Sarah's mental health treatment. It helped her express her feelings in a healthy way and gave her a sense of peace and purpose. Art therapy not only helped Sarah but also helped her family and friends understand her struggles better. It's a testament to the power of creativity and how it can heal even the deepest wounds.

You have to understand that moderators are not appointed or elected by reddit (the company). Reddit is setup so that anyone can create their own subreddits. The people who create the subreddits are called moderators. They can then appoint other people to help them moderate the subreddit. The people who moderate a subreddit are responsible for enforcing the rules of that subreddit. They can also remove posts and comments that they feel are inappropriate.

Counter-argument: While it may seem like changing one's public stance on issues is acceptable, it can also be seen as untrustworthy and lacking conviction in one's beliefs. Voters rely on politicians to maintain their values and principles, and if they are prone to flip-flopping, it could have negative effects on trust and credibility. It also raises the question of whether the politician is genuinely committed to the issues or is simply changing their stance for political gain. Consistency in beliefs is key in building trust with constituents and maintaining accountability for political decisions. Therefore, politicians should be encouraged to stay true to their values and beliefs, and not change their stance on issues without careful consideration and deep reflection.

In a groundbreaking new study, researchers have found that microdosing LSD could be an effective treatment for Alzheimer's disease. In the early human trial, which was conducted by a team at the University of California, San Diego, patients were given a small dose of LSD over the course of two weeks and were monitored to track their progress. The results showed that the patients experienced no adverse effects, suggesting that microdosing LSD may be a safe and effective way to treat symptoms of Alzheimer's. The study is still ongoing and more research is needed, but this initial trial has raised hopes that a novel, non-pharmaceutical approach to treating Alzheimer's may be possible.

On older typewriters, the keys would cause levers or "arms" to move up to the paper and stamp the letters as you pressed the keys. Too often, frequently used keys would cause the machine to jam when the arms would get wedged together at the paper. So the qwerty keyboard was invented to decrease the odds of this happening. Once electronic keyboards came along, the qwerty system stayed since that's what people were used to.

Being true to oneself is a fundamental aspect of life. In a society that places a high value on conformity and expectations, it can be difficult to remain true to oneself. However, it is important to do so, as it is essential for personal growth and happiness.

One of the main reasons why it is important to be true to oneself is that it allows for personal growth. When we try to fit into someone else's mold, we stifle our own unique qualities and talents. By being true to ourselves, we allow ourselves to explore our own passions and interests, which can lead to personal growth and fulfillment.

Additionally, being true to oneself can also lead to greater happiness. When we try to fit into someone else's mold, we often feel like we are not living our best lives. This can lead to feelings of unhappiness and dissatisfaction. By being true to ourselves, we can live our lives on our own terms, which can lead to greater happiness and satisfaction.

However, it can be difficult to remain true to oneself in a society that places a high value on conformity. Family and societal expectations can be powerful forces, and it can be tempting to try to fit into someone else's mold in order to please them. However, it is important to remember that our own happiness and fulfillment should be our top priority.

In conclusion, being true to oneself is essential for personal growth and happiness. While it can be difficult to remain true to oneself in a society that places a high value on conformity, it is important to do so. By being true to ourselves, we can live our lives on our own terms, which can lead to greater happiness and fulfillment.

Trevithick continued his own experiments using a trio of locomotives, concluding with the Catch Me Who Can in 1808. Only four years later, the successful twin-cylinder locomotive Salamanca by Matthew Murray began operation on the edge-railed rack-and-pinion Middleton Railway. Murray's design included a return-flue boiler, allowing a locomotive to last longer between cleaning. Salamanca ran for 3 12 miles (5.6 km) and is regarded by some as the world's first successful steam locomotive.[12] The Liverpool and Manchester Railway, built by Stephenson and his son Robert's company Robert Stephenson and Company, opened in 1830. It was the world's first intercity passenger railway operated by steam locomotives only, without animal or human power input. The LM's initial period of operation was also the first period of rapid railway construction, with the over 1,100 miles (1,800 km) of track built in Britain between 1830 and 1839 transforming the country's economy.[345]

I was clearly born in the wrong time period. I should have been born in the 40s, so that I could make it just in time for the musical revolution that was the sixties: the Beatles, the Velvet Underground, the Who, everything that was good and holy. Furthermore, I am an old school rocker. Furthermore, I have all the symptoms. A contemptuous outlook on the course of modern rock, a sense of elitist arrogance in my own music taste, and of course, the ability to make sophisticated and profound comments on what sometimes sound like absolute crap. Yet, Rock and Roll isn't always about being a jerk. Rock has made me who I am. I'm the sarcastic girl who wears lots of eyeliner and kisses her John Lennon poster goodnight. But I'm also the girl who can converse for hours about the two great Jimmy's, Hendrix and Page, who cultivated her reading and writing abilities from reading countless biographies of rock stars, who adopted her sense of humor from the quips of Ringo Starr. Class of 2014, I offer you the voice of a generation before ours: the voice of the sixties, and the sense of freedom and possibility that came with it. ---- any suggestions greatly appreciated!!!

Drivers Should Not Use Cell Phones in Any Capacity While Driving

In today's world, cell phones have become indispensable tools that many people rely on daily. However, using a cell phone while driving a vehicle can be extremely dangerous and poses significant risks. For this reason, drivers should not be allowed to use cell phones in any capacity when operating a motor vehicle.

There are several reasons why cell phone use behind the wheel is unsafe. Firstly, it is a severe distraction from the task of driving. Answering calls, responding to texts, checking social media, or other phone activities take the driver's eyes off the road and mind off their surroundings. This hinders a driver's ability to pay attention to the road, other vehicles, pedestrians, traffic lights and signs. Even hands-free phone use requires cognitive attention that should be focused on operating the vehicle safely. 

Secondly, studies have shown that driving while distracted by a phone is comparable to driving drunk or distracted. Such distractions significantly increase the risk of accidents on the road. Drivers engaged with cell phones are less aware of their surroundings and slower to react to potential hazards. This puts not only the driver at risk but also endangers other motorists, cyclists and pedestrians sharing the road.

Lastly, prohibiting cell phone use supports other traffic safety laws. Not paying attention or careless driving due to phone engagement can often be the primary cause of accidents. Banning phones upholds the responsibility of drivers to remain alert and in control of their vehicle at all times. It recognizes that public roads require the full, undivided focus of anyone operating a motor vehicle.

In conclusion, the dangers of cell phone use while driving far outweigh any perceived need or benefit. Lives are at stake with every vehicle on the road. To promote traffic safety and prevent accidents, drivers should not be allowed to hold, view, dial or send messages on any electronic device when operating a motor vehicle. Full attention and control of the vehicle must be the top priority to keep our roads safe for all.

Dear Senator,

I am writing to you today to voice my support for abolishing the Electoral College and electing the President of the United States by popular vote.

The Electoral College is a system that was created in 1787 by the Founding Fathers. At the time, the country was much smaller and less populated than it is today. The Electoral College was designed to give more power to the smaller states, as they would have less of a voice in a direct election.

However, the country has changed dramatically since the Electoral College was created. The United States is now the third most populous country in the world, and the Electoral College is no longer necessary to give a voice to the smaller states. In fact, the Electoral College gives an unfair advantage to the small states, as they have a disproportionate number of electoral votes.

The Electoral College also leads to the possibility of a candidate winning the popular vote but losing the election. This has happened five times in American history, most recently in 2016. When this happens, it undermines the legitimacy of the election and leaves millions of Americans feeling like their votes do not matter.

There are many reasons why I believe that the Electoral College should be abolished. First, it is undemocratic. The Electoral College gives more power to some voters than others, simply because of where they live. This is not fair, and it is not in line with the principle of one person, one vote.

Second, the Electoral College is not always representative of the will of the people. In 2016, for example, Hillary Clinton won the popular vote by nearly 3 million votes, but she lost the election because she did not win enough electoral votes. This is a clear example of how the Electoral College can lead to an unfair result.

Third, the Electoral College is unnecessary. The United States is now a large and diverse country, and the Electoral College is no longer necessary to give a voice to the smaller states. In fact, the Electoral College gives a disproportionate advantage to the small states, as they have a disproportionate number of electoral votes.

I urge you to support a constitutional amendment that would abolish the Electoral College and elect the President of the United States by popular vote. This would be a fair and democratic way to choose our leaders.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

In the United States, cars are a way of life. We rely on them to get to work, school, the grocery store, and everywhere in between. But our reliance on cars is having a negative impact on our environment, our economy, and our health.

One of the biggest problems with cars is that they produce a lot of pollution. When we drive, our cars emit carbon dioxide, which is a greenhouse gas that contributes to climate change. Cars also emit other pollutants, such as nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, which can cause respiratory problems and other health issues.

In addition to the environmental problems, cars also contribute to traffic congestion. When too many people are driving, it can create traffic jams that can make it difficult to get where we're going. Traffic congestion can also waste time and fuel.

Finally, cars are expensive. The cost of owning a car includes the initial purchase price, the cost of insurance, gas, and maintenance. These costs can be a burden for many people, especially those who live in low-income communities.

There are a number of things we can do to reduce our reliance on cars. One option is to carpool or take public transportation. This can help to reduce traffic congestion and pollution. Another option is to walk or bike. This is a great way to get exercise and fresh air. And finally, we can choose to live in communities that are designed for walking, biking, and public transportation.

Limiting car usage has a number of benefits. It can help to improve air quality, reduce traffic congestion, and save money. It can also be a healthier option, as it encourages us to be more active. And finally, it can make our communities more livable, as it creates a more walkable and bikeable environment.

If we want to create a more sustainable future, we need to find ways to limit our reliance on cars. By carpooling, taking public transportation, walking, biking, and choosing to live in communities that are designed for walking, biking, and public transportation, we can make a difference.

So here it is, my first ever Film Review. Please do read, i will appreciate it a lot.  
  
So today I went to watch M.S. Dhoni :The Untold Story. It was indeed a much anticipated movie by the cricket fans and why shouldn't it be, it was after all about a big Cricket star, who is loved by a lot of people. But to be honest, it was not that amazing or excellent as it could have been.  
  
The first minus point of the movie was that it was unnecessarily long, and even after being too long, the most striking or relevant details of the Indian cricket Team captain's life were missed out.The progression of the movie lacked in liveliness. Sometimes in between the movie, you sit and try to figure what just happened. What the film lacks is the charismatic energy which could have been if the Direction would have been better.  
  
The movie might not also appeal to hardcore Cricket fans, because seriously it lacked a lot of the cricket part.  
  
But the plus side of the movie were the emotional songs(though at times, the unnecessary sound kind of annoyed me). And the best part of the direction was the Death of Priyanka ( Mahendra singh Dhoni's first Girlfriend ).And the best part of the movie was the Inidan feel that one got from it, the small and trivial Indian things which were shown were very good.  
  
Overall, the movie was a fair shot and is a must watch if someone is a big M.S. Dhoni fan but it fails to draw up that energy, the thrill of the last Shot by M.S. Dhoni in 2011World Cup, it was kind of mediocre, as it was considered the main attraction of the movie, and therefore, much more anticipation could have been built up but there wasn't any And I still prefer seeing the Six shot by Dhoni on my 32 inch screen T.V and having uncontrolled goosies rather than the big Picture. Though the last scene was very Emotional(the one with the trophies in the hand of the Men-In-Blue).  
  
So, thank you if you have read till now, You certainly were an ardent reader and this was my opinion , i would recommend you to definitely watch it and have some of your own.

The Role of Renewable Energy in Combating Climate Change

Climate change is one of the most pressing issues of our time. It is the result of the accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, which traps heat and causes the Earth's temperature to rise. Climate change is having a profound impact on the planet, causing droughts, floods, and other extreme weather events. The good news is that there is something we can do about it. Renewable energy is one of the most promising solutions to the problem of climate change.

Renewable energy refers to energy that is generated from natural sources that are replenished over time. These sources include wind, solar, geothermal, and biomass. Unlike fossil fuels, which are finite and will eventually run out, renewable energy sources are inexhaustible. This means that we can continue to generate renewable energy for as long as we need it, without fear of running out.

One of the most significant advantages of renewable energy is that it produces little or no greenhouse gas emissions. Fossil fuels, on the other hand, are responsible for the release of large amounts of carbon dioxide and other pollutants into the atmosphere. By transitioning to renewable energy sources, we can significantly reduce our carbon footprint and slow the pace of climate change.

Renewable energy also has the potential to create new jobs and stimulate economic growth. The renewable energy industry is already one of the fastest-growing industries in the world, and as more countries shift towards renewable energy, this growth is expected to continue. This means that there will be increasing opportunities for people to work in the renewable energy sector, and this will help to stimulate economic growth.

In conclusion, renewable energy has a critical role to play in combating climate change. By transitioning away from fossil fuels and towards renewable energy sources, we can reduce our carbon footprint, stimulate economic growth, and create a more sustainable future for ourselves and for future generations. While the transition will not be easy, it is essential if we are to avert the worst effects of climate change.

Manchester United midfielder Paul Pogba launched his very own Twitter emoji last Sunday, which caught the attention of fans and critics alike. Pogba's Twitter emoji features his signature 'dab' celebration and is set to be available on Twitter for the remainder of the season. He is one of the first football players in the world to have his own custom emoji, which shows his popularity and influence both on and off the pitch. Manchester United's victory against Chelsea, with Pogba putting in a solid performance, only added to the hype around the player, who has been one of the standout performers for the club this season. His partnership with Ibrahimovic has also been crucial to the team's success, with the two players combining for multiple goals this season. Pogba will be hoping that his good form continues, with Manchester United still in the race for a top-four finish in the Premier League. With his own Twitter emoji to boot, it seems like the attention on him will only continue to grow, but as Ibrahimovic pointed out, Pogba is a pro who can handle it.

Though John Wesley originally wanted the Methodists to stay within the Church of England, the American Revolution decisively separated the Methodists in the American colonies from the life and sacraments of the Anglican Church. In 1784, after unsuccessful attempts to have the Church of England send a bishop to start a new church in the colonies, Wesley decisively appointed fellow priest Thomas Coke as superintendent (bishop) to organize a separate Methodist Society. Together with Coke, Wesley sent a revision of the Anglican Prayerbook and the Articles of Religion which were received and adopted by the Baltimore Christmas Conference of 1784, officially establishing the Methodist Episcopal Church. The conference was held at the Lovely Lane Methodist Church, considered the Mother Church of American Methodism.

Carnival has been celebrated for centuries. The tradition was likely established under Venetian rule around the 16th century. It may have been influenced by Greek traditions, such as festivities for deities such as Dionysus. The celebration originally involved dressing in costumes and holding masked balls or visiting friends. In the twentieth century it became an organized event held during the 10 days preceding Lent (according to the Greek Orthodox calendar). The festival is celebrated almost exclusively in the city of Limassol.

Title: An Unforgettable Journey to Generic City

Introduction

Welcome to Generic City, a vibrant metropolis filled with iconic landmarks, world-class museums, and picturesque natural beauty. In this comprehensive guide, we will take you through a carefully planned trip that encompasses the best attractions and experiences that Generic City has to offer. From exploring historical sites like the White House and Abraham Lincoln Memorial to immersing yourself in diverse art collections at renowned museums, our itinerary ensures a memorable journey for travelers of all ages and interests. So pack your bags, grab your camera, and let's embark on this unforgettable adventure!

Day One: Arrival and Historical Landmarks

Upon arriving in Generic City, check into your hotel and freshen up before starting your sightseeing tour. Begin your day at the heart of the city - the National Mall. This sprawling green space stretches from the U.S. Capitol Building to the Potomac River and is home to numerous monuments and museums. Your first stop should be the White House, the official residence of the President of the United States. Join a guided tour to explore the stately rooms and learn about its rich history.

Next, make your way to the Washington Monument, an obelisk that commemorates George Washington, the nation's first president. Take the elevator to the top for panoramic views of the city. Then, head over to the Jefferson Memorial, which honors another founding father, Thomas Jefferson. Admire the neoclassical architecture and beautiful gardens surrounding the memorial.

End your day with a visit to the Abraham Lincoln Memorial, a tribute to America's 16th president who played a pivotal role in abolishing slavery. Reflect upon his legacy while marveling at the majestic statue of Lincoln seated within the temple-like structure.

Day Two: Museum Hopping and Cultural Experiences

Begin your second day by delving into the fascinating world of aviation and space exploration at the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum. Here, you'll find an incredible collection of aircraft, spacecraft, and interactive exhibits that showcase humanity's achievements in flight and beyond. Highlights include the Wright Brothers' Flyer, Charles Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis, and even a piece of moon rock.

Afterward, indulge your love for the arts at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, where you can admire works spanning from the colonial period to contemporary times. Marvel at paintings by Edward Hopper, Georgia O'Keeffe, and other prominent artists, as well as intriguing installations and multimedia displays.

In the afternoon, immerse yourself in global culture at the Smithsonian National Museum of Natural History. Discover an extensive array of artifacts, specimens, and fossils that reveal the wonders of our planet and its inhabitants. Don't miss the famous Hope Diamond, a breathtaking 45-carat gemstone, and the life-size replica of a blue whale suspended above the main hall.

Sage, I don't get the point of this research paper. The extremely ill formatted opening paragraph does not contain any thesis statement. It is just a bunch of information that doesn't really create a direction for the paper. Nor does it contain any information that would tell me, as the reader, what this paper will be all about. Here is a suggestion, rather than just throwing together a bunch of ideas onscreen and hoping that it will come together, why don't you try to outline the paper first. That way you can review this collection of information and then decide which goes and which stays for your research paper.  
  
The most important part of the research you have to come up with first, is the thesis statement. So make that the topmost part of your outline. From there, pick out the relevant information from this draft and position them in the outline according to relevance and importance in the presentation. Don't forget, these should represent the main and sub-topics of your research.  
  
From that point, you should be able to better assess your information on hand in relation to your thesis statement. You have some pretty solid information in this draft. They just don't make any sense at the moment. Proper positioning, in response to the questions that your thesis statement hopes to provide answers to will help a lot in this instance.

The world is full of mysteries, and one of the most intriguing ones is the existence of parallel universes. Imagine a reality where you made a different choice at a crucial moment in your life, and now you're living the consequences of that decision. Perhaps you're married to someone else, or you have a different career path. The possibilities are endless, and it's both fascinating and terrifying to think about.

Parallel universes have been explored in various forms of media, from science fiction books to movies and TV shows. In these stories, characters often travel between dimensions to explore these alternative realities. Some encounter versions of themselves who have led different lives, while others face the consequences of their actions in a parallel universe.

There is some scientific evidence that supports the idea of parallel universes, such as the theory of quantum mechanics. This theory suggests that particles can exist in multiple states at the same time until observed, at which point they "collapse" into a single state. Some scientists believe that these parallel states could be separate universes.

However, there are also many skeptics who argue that the existence of parallel universes is purely theoretical and has no concrete evidence to support it. They believe that the idea is simply a product of science fiction and doesn't hold up under scientific scrutiny.

Personally, I'm intrigued by the concept of parallel universes. It's an idea that challenges our understanding of reality and opens up endless possibilities for exploration. While I understand the skepticism, I also believe that there is more to the universe than what we can currently comprehend. Who knows, maybe one day we'll discover that parallel universes do exist, and we'll be able to explore them firsthand.

By definition, a patent must describe the invention in such a way that an expert could copy the invention from the description. This is called the sufficiency of disclosure. The disclosure can be complex (not like an ELI5) and possibly only understood by other drug manufacturers as in your example. Patents give an inventor a monopoly in bringing an invention to the marketplace. This means that the inventor is the only one who can profit from an invention for a limited time. In exchange for this protection, the inventor tells the world about his or her invention so that everyone can benefit from it after this monopoly ends. The monopoly is seen as a motivator for the progress of science. We find this rationale written into the U.S. Constitution, "The Congress shall have power.... To promote the progress of science and useful arts, by securing for limited times to authors and inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries." An inventor can decide to keep his or her invention a secret. Trade secrets are a form of protection that an inventor can use if he or she thinks that it is unlikely that someone will independently invent the same thing. A drug manufacturer may invent a cool process for making drugs and keep this hidden from the public. The risk in this situation is that someone may discover the same invention independently and use it themselves. On the other hand, a patent will cover independent inventions that do the same thing. For instance, the guy who invented the waxed paper that accepts ink (the kind we find on every TV dinner in existence) was protected against a different company who invented the same thing under a completely different formula. So, a drug company must decide what they disclose in both their process and forumula and weigh the benefit of the monopoly against the limitation of the patent and the risk of an independent discovery. In some cases a generic manufacturer may have the forumula, but not the process so the generic drugs may be slightly different from the name brand medication. If you have ever watched the tv show Breaking Bad, (MINOR SPOILER ALERT) you will see that Walter White changes the process and forumula for making crystal meth during the course of the show several times. It's still crystal meth, but the users comment on how the "quality" of the product changes over time. Generic manufactures aren't exactly making medications in an RV parked in the desert, but if they don't have the facilities and process of the named brand manufacturer, there is the possibility that the medication could be effectively different.

As the world grapples with the devastating effects of climate change, one group that stands to lose the most is indigenous communities. These communities have long lived in harmony with their environment, relying on traditional knowledge and practices passed down through generations. However, the rapid changes brought about by global warming threaten not only their way of life but also their cultural heritage. This paper will delve into the various ways in which climate change impacts indigenous cultural heritage and discuss potential solutions for mitigating these negative consequences.
Climate change has numerous direct and indirect effects on indigenous cultures around the globe. One significant impact is the loss of ancestral lands due to rising sea levels, desertification, and other environmental factors. For example, many low-lying islands inhabited by Pacific Islander communities are at risk of being submerged underwater, forcing residents to abandon their homes and relocate elsewhere. Similarly, droughts and floods caused by changing weather patterns displace indigenous populations living in arid regions such as the Sahel in Africa or the American Southwest. Losing access to their native lands often results in the erosion of traditional lifestyles, customs, and languages, thereby undermining the unique cultural identities of these groups.
Moreover, shifting temperatures and precipitation levels lead to changes in ecosystems that support indigenous livelihoods. In the Arctic, melting ice sheets endanger the survival of polar bears and seals - critical sources of food and materials for local tribes. Warmer ocean waters cause coral bleaching events that destroy vital fisheries upon which coastal indigenous societies depend. Meanwhile, deforestation triggered by extreme weather events reduces the availability of medicinal plants crucial to many indigenous healing traditions. Such disruptions to natural resources jeopardize both the physical well-being and spiritual connections of indigenous peoples to their environments.
Another consequence of climate change is its exacerbation of existing social issues within indigenous communities. For instance, increased competition over scarce resources may heighten tensions among different tribal factions or fuel conflicts with non-indigenous settlers encroaching onto traditionally owned lands. Additionally, displacement resulting from environmental degradation can strain already limited government services designed to assist vulnerable populations, leading to further marginalization and poverty.
Despite the daunting challenges posed by climate change, there are several promising strategies for safeguarding indigenous cultural heritage while adapting to new realities. Firstly, policymakers must prioritize the inclusion of indigenous voices in decision-making processes related to climate action plans and resource management. By recognizing their rights to self-determination and consultation, governments can ensure that measures taken

It has announced changes to the heavily criticised and regularly overspent Cancer Drugs Fund, which pays for drugs the NHS has deemed unaffordable. The new system will start in July 2016 and have a fixed budget of PS340m. No patients receiving drugs on the old Cancer Drugs Fund will have their medication stopped. At present, the CDF can choose to pay for innovative drugs the health watchdog, the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE), has rejected for widespread use on the NHS. But under the new system, NICE will make all the decisions. By the time a drug comes on to the market, NICE will give it a yes, no or maybe rating. Those given the go-ahead will be routinely offered across the NHS while those given a maybe rating can be considered for the CDF. However, there will be "clear entry and exit criteria" to ensure money is spent on only the best breakthrough drugs. Bruce Keogh, medical director at NHS England, said: "Improving cancer care is an absolute priority for NHS England.... that is dependent on access to treatments. The CDF] will provide faster access for patients, I think that's really important, and I think it will bring clarity to which drugs are the most effective sooner than we know at the moment." The fund, which was established in 2011 and covers England, has seen its costs rise to PS340m in 2015-16 from an initial annual budget of PS200m. An NHS official said: "Drug companies will need to price their drugs responsibly, and we make no apology for maintaining the pressure on this point on behalf of the public. "Companies keen to work with the NHS for patients will get a new fast-track route to NHS funding for promising new drugs, backed by a speeded up and more transparent NICE assessment process." Dr Paul Catchpole, from the Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry, said: "If cancer medicines go through more or less exactly the same NICE appraisal process that was in place five years ago - which necessitated the setting up of the CDF in the first place - we will largely get the same answers as before - the majority of medicines will be turned down. "Without substantial changes the ABPI estimates that under the proposals two thirds of existing CDF medicines are likely to no longer be available to NHS patients by the end of the year." Target Ovarian Cancer chief executive Annwen Jones said: "Important questions remain unanswered with this proposal. "The Cancer Drugs Fund must retain the power to make a real difference to people's lives in the face of budget cuts." Follow James on Twitter.
