Philosophy of Privacy and Governmental Surveillance Essay

This work aims to analyze how humanistic ideas about private life have been transformed in the modern world. Philosophers John Locke and Thomas Hobbes formed traditional ideas about the inviolability of private property and personal life. Locke’s ideas about private property formed one of the major amendments to the text of the American constitution (Kanatli, 2021). Considering how these ideas have been transformed in the digital age, one can understand how far society and official institutions have moved away from these theoretical calculations.

The social contract is Hobbes’s theory that the state is necessary for people in order to make their life full and safe. In the context of the widespread surveillance of private information on the Internet by American intelligence agencies, the traditional ideas of humanism seem distorted or wholly violated. Interviews given by Google and Facebook officials at the beginning of the last decade make it clear that the Internet has a full list of rights to information uploaded by a person (Weinberg, 2018). In the context of a social contract, this violation of rights can be explained by the voluntary renunciation of them by people in the name of their own security. However, it is obvious that initially the Internet was positioned as a space not only for socialization but also for privacy (Cloud, 2018). The very fact of round-the-clock monitoring of people through devices and social networks was initially, hidden by the state, which accordingly cancels the very logic of the contract.

The state does not have the right to create a permanent surveillance mechanism because it hurts the very essence of the right to freedom. Therefore, the very statement about the legality of such practices is false since there was no conscious consent to it. The social contract for constant surveillance is rather a mechanism of infringement of rights, limiting and normalizing the range of possible human behavior.

Surveillance boundaries can be determined by video filming of public spaces with a large crowd of people, which is adequate in the context of a terrorist threat. The perusal of correspondence on the network is an unconditional invasion of a person’s private life. The state should stop controlling social networks, except for the most private precedents, giving people the opportunity to express themselves and develop society freely.

References

Cloud, M. (2018). Property is privacy: Locke and Brandeis in the twenty-first century. American Criminal Literature Review, 55, 37-75.

Kanatli, M. (2021). Private property, freedom and order social contract theories from Hobbes to Rawls. Routledge India.

Weinberg, G. (2018). Google and Facebook are watching our every move online. It’s time to make them stop. CNBC . Web.

My eyes opened to the window with the heavy paint, looking out at the old oak tree. It waved at me in the wind, and the sun brought color out into its bright red and yellow leaves. As the air shifted, many took flight, letting loose a few to the free fall, as branches shifted. Breathing was easy as I lay there, still, loose, and narrow. My back didn't hurt, my legs were tingling in anticipation of movement. Nothing cracked or groaned as I sat up. I just felt "right." Everything was so damn bright, new, amazing. I tried to not lose myself in it as I got up, rolling from my old bed, in my old house. My eyes didn't need glasses, the room was crystal clear. Luna, my old cat looked at me with a casual glance before she settled down again on the covers of it. Her hair was white, fluffy, soft, and she smelled like the flowers set on the counter she always ate when no one was home. I weighed next to nothing, as if my body was just..... just strong- like I was three times as strong as I'd been when I went to sleep the night before. I wanted to cry, to dance, to run, to move- I had to move! The day had just started, and everything was so strange! As I ran down the stairs, I jumped the last few, landing with a thud- but bouncing back up like a rocket towards the kitchen, and out the back door. The air was fresh, the sky blue, the clouds were white and beautiful as the grass and sand beneath my toes. Christ, I wanted to cry. "Come get breakfast! I'll make you eggs." Her voice was just as I remembered it, and I couldn't help but give in. I did cry then. The day went on, and I knew somehow- I just knew, that when I woke up tomorrow I would be back. I would be me as I was, that this was a fluke and a chance. This was a miracle, and if I had any guts at all- I should take it, change what I could, while I could. I didn't do that though. Instead, I spent the day with my mom and I didn't change a thing.

The federal government continued to provide similar contractual relations with the Indian tribes after 1871 by agreements, statutes, and executive orders.

The Illusive Man appeared on the hologram one final time before Commander Shepard. "Shepard, I'm telling you, we can control the Reapers! Are you willing to pass up the opportunity to do what is necessary to save humanity?" he asked, his voice filled with conviction. Commander Shepard regarded the hologram for several long moments before responding. "I can't ignore everything I've seen, everything I know about the Reapers. They're not something that can be controlled, Illusive Man. They're a force of nature, and we need to find a way to stop them, not control them." The Illusive Man's expression hardened. "You're making a mistake, Shepard. You're throwing away our best chance to come out of this alive." Shepard stood firm. "I won't sacrifice everything that makes us human just to win this war. I won't become like the Reapers." The Illusive Man sighed, his hologram flickering slightly. "You're a stubborn one, Shepard. But mark my words, you'll regret this decision." And with that, the hologram vanished, leaving Shepard alone in the room. The Commander couldn't help but feel a twinge of regret at the thought of what could have been, but ultimately knew that the Illusive Man's vision was not the way forward. There had to be another way to defeat the Reapers and save the galaxy, without compromising humanity's own values and integrity.

Lancashire batsman Livingstone, who scored 129 from 83 balls for England Lions against South Africa A last week, is one of five uncapped players named. Mason Crane, Dawid Malan, Tom Curran and Craig Overton are the other four players yet to make their debut. The three-match series starts in Southampton on 21 June. England lost their last Twenty20 series 2-1 to India in February. Moeen Ali, Jake Ball, Adil Rashid, Joe Root and Ben Stokes have been rested and will instead play for their respective counties in the inaugural day-night round of the County Championship, which starts on 26 June. This will allow them to gain experience of playing with the pink Dukes balls that will be used for the first day-night Test to be played in England, against West Indies at Edgbaston in August. Sussex fast bowler Tymal Mills, meanwhile, has been ruled out with a back injury, but Durham seamer Mark Wood returns after missing the India series through injury. Middlesex opener Malan, Surrey paceman Curran and Somerset all-rounder Overton have previously been included in England squads, while Hampshire leg-spinner Crane is called up after impressing in the North-South series in March. Overton will replace Wood in the squad after the first match, while wicketkeeper Jonny Bairstow will be available for the first two matches before returning to Yorkshire. Jason Roy, who has managed just 18 runs in three innings for England in the ongoing Champions Trophy, is named in the squad. Chairman of selectors James Whitaker said: "The squad has an exciting blend of youth and experience and we are looking forward to a competitive series against strong opposition. "With five uncapped players selected, there is undoubted talent coming through the system and we are excited to see some of these players showcase their skills at the highest level." BBC Radio Lancashire's Scott Read There is a touch of Kevin Pietersen about Liam Livingstone when he gets onto the front foot to pull through mid-wicket. He is a powerful, destructive batsman who in white-ball cricket has the ability to take games away from the opposition and is great fun to watch.

The colour of the sky is caused by sunlight light bouncing around within the atmosphere. At night, on earth, there's no sunlight so it appears black. On the moon there's no atmosphere, so the moon looks the same as the sky on earth. However, it does look different in different parts of the night. The light from the moon will only reach the surface of the moon at certain times. As a result, it will look a different colour at different times. A: When we talk about the color of the moon, we're not really talking about the color of the surface. It's a mix of light from the sun, the atmosphere and the moon itself. When the sun is out, the moon is invisible, so it doesn't have a surface color. When the sun is below the horizon, we can see the moon, but it's completely white. The light from the moon is reflected off the atmosphere, and the reflected light is slightly different from the reflected light from the sun. The reflected light from the moon is the same color as the reflected light from the sun, so the moon is white at this time. When the sun is directly overhead, the moon is illuminated by sunlight, and it appears the same color as the sun. When the sun is directly overhead, the moon is illuminated by sunlight, and it appears the same color as the sun. This happens every day. It's just that on the side of the moon that's closer to the sun, it looks more orange. When the moon is directly above the sun, it's not illuminated by sunlight, so it's dark. The moon is always dark at this time. When the moon is directly above the sun, it's not illuminated by sunlight, so it's dark. The moon is always dark at this time.

We propose a decentralized game-theoretic framework for dynamic task allocation problems for multi-agent systems. In our problem formulation, the agents' utilities depend on both the rewards and the costs associated with each task. Structural rules that distinguish between tasks are defined in order to reduce the number of computation operations necessary for all tasks (interval or burst). We offer an alternative call to this rule system: we recommend the following approach: rather than adhering to one particular size of the network, we consider a randomized set of discrete nodes divided by their total computing power. The result is a distributed fault-tolerant network which accepts errors in the way it handles many outputs at once. This kind of graph resembles the idea that networks can be distributed symmetrically as well as with regard to its distribution. Language: en

There are a few reasons why there are relatively few ancient human remains. One factor is that over time, many remains have likely deteriorated or been destroyed by natural processes. In addition, some remains may have been purposely destroyed or discarded by ancient peoples for cultural or religious reasons. Migration and displacement may have also played a role in the loss or scattering of remains, especially before the advent of modern transportation and preservation methods. Finally, the discovery and preservation of ancient remains is often a matter of chance and requires a combination of factors such as favorable soil conditions, careful excavation techniques, and the right tools for analysis.

The Effects of Social Media on Teenagers' Sleep Patterns

Social media has become an integral part of our daily lives. It is hard to imagine a day without checking our phones, scrolling through our feeds, and connecting with others online. However, the effects of social media on teenagers' sleep patterns have become a cause of concern for many parents and experts. This essay will explore the effects of social media on teenagers' sleep patterns, the negative consequences, and provide a solution to mitigate these issues.

First, let's consider the effects of social media on teenagers' sleep patterns. Studies have shown that exposure to screens, particularly before bedtime, can disrupt our sleep cycles. The blue light emitted by screens can suppress melatonin production, which is a hormone responsible for regulating sleep. As a result, teenagers who use social media before bedtime may have difficulty falling asleep, experience poor sleep quality, and feel fatigued during the day.

Moreover, social media can also affect teenagers' sleep patterns by causing them to stay up late. The constant stimulation of social media can be addictive, leading teenagers to spend hours scrolling through their feeds. This can result in a lack of sleep, which can have negative consequences on their physical and mental health.

The negative consequences of social media on teenagers' sleep patterns can be significant. Poor sleep quality can lead to a range of health problems such as obesity, diabetes, and depression. Furthermore, lack of sleep can also affect teenagers' academic performance, leading to poor grades and a decreased ability to concentrate.

To mitigate these issues, it is essential to establish boundaries around social media use. Parents can play a critical role in setting these boundaries by limiting screen time before bedtime and encouraging their teenagers to engage in other activities such as reading a book or taking a walk. Additionally, teenagers can benefit from establishing a regular sleep schedule, setting aside time for social media use, and avoiding screens for at least an hour before bedtime.

In conclusion, social media has a significant impact on teenagers' sleep patterns. The effects can be detrimental to their physical and mental health, and academic performance. However, by establishing boundaries around social media use and setting a regular sleep schedule, teenagers can mitigate these issues and enjoy a better quality of life.

The third assessment report (TAR) prominently featured a graph labeled "Millennial Northern Hemisphere temperature reconstruction" based on a 1999 paper by Michael E. Mann, Raymond S. Bradley and Malcolm K. Hughes titled "A Reconstruction of Temperatures in the Northern Hemisphere for the Last 1,000 Years." The graph showed an apparent hiatus between in global temperatures that late last year was noted as being caused by natural variability. But after further analysis, the authors concluded: "We have not found evidence to support this claim about any possible pause." Rather than drawing the conclusion from the TAR data set alone, they used additional databases that had been developed since 1997 (see chart). They also added climate models to their research methodology. By doing so, the team could be sure what it was examining is indeed the cause of the recent warming trend. Among other things, they incorporated "sea surface temperature observations from the Goddard Institute for Space Studies Coastal Ocean Temperature Anomaly Dataset," which has collected daily sea surface temperature measurements at more than 140 locations around the world since 1984. As a result, they were able to determine whether or not there really was such a dramatic cooling period during the second half of the 20th century. Mann and his colleagues, including lead author Steve McIntyre, found no basis for concluding that there was a real linear break in the average annual mean temperature trend over the 20th century. But if you combine the new analyses with those obtained from the first three TAR reports, it becomes clear why scientists and leading politicians saw significant value in using the graph's appearance to suggest human influence on climate change even without physical evidence to back up that claim. It appears researchers may have cherry picked certain items out of a complex climate dataset to come up with a preferred outcome. The Paris Climate Accord says we need to limit our CO2 emissions to avoid dangerous levels of global warming; but how does anyone know we shouldn't use this study to justify our continued dependence on fossil fuels? In the absence of hard scientific proof, should we just ignore all the inconvenient facts and keep drilling for oil and coal?

Cars have become an integral part of our lives. We use them to get to work, run errands, and take our children to school. But there are a number of advantages to limiting car usage.

First, limiting car usage can help to reduce pollution. Cars are a major source of air pollution, which can cause respiratory problems, heart disease, and other health issues. When we drive less, we help to improve air quality and make the air we breathe healthier.

Second, limiting car usage can help to reduce traffic congestion. Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities, and it can cause a lot of stress and wasted time. When we drive less, we help to reduce traffic congestion and make our roads more efficient.

Third, limiting car usage can help to save money. Cars are expensive to buy, maintain, and fuel. When we drive less, we save money on gas, car insurance, and car repairs.

Fourth, limiting car usage can help us to get more exercise. When we walk or bike instead of driving, we get some much-needed exercise. Exercise is good for our physical and mental health, and it can help us to lose weight and reduce our risk of chronic diseases.

Fifth, limiting car usage can help us to connect with our community. When we walk or bike instead of driving, we have a chance to see our neighbors and get to know them. We also have a chance to explore our community and discover new places.

In conclusion, there are a number of advantages to limiting car usage. Limiting car usage can help to reduce pollution, reduce traffic congestion, save money, get more exercise, and connect with our community. If we all make an effort to drive less, we can make a big difference for our environment, our economy, and our health.

In addition to the advantages listed above, limiting car usage can also help to improve our quality of life. When we spend less time in our cars, we have more time to do the things we enjoy. We can spend time with our family and friends, pursue our hobbies, and relax. We can also use the time we save to get more exercise, which can improve our physical and mental health.

Limiting car usage can also help us to save money. Cars are expensive to buy, maintain, and fuel. When we drive less, we save money on these costs. We can also save money on parking fees, which can be expensive in some cities.

Finally, limiting car usage can help to reduce our carbon footprint. Cars are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions, which contribute to climate change. When we drive less, we help to reduce our impact on the environment.

For all of these reasons, I believe that it is important to limit car usage. If we all make an effort to drive less, we can make a big difference for our environment, our economy, and our quality of life.

Apple, the world's largest technology company, just made a big move in the film industry by acquiring the rights to a movie from Sundance. The movie follows two strangers who get stuck in a time loop and have to figure out how to escape it. It was one of the most talked about films at this year's Sundance Film Festival, earning rave reviews from critics. Apple is no stranger to investing in original content, having recently launched their own streaming service, Apple TV. But this acquisition marks the first time they've bought the rights to a movie from Sundance. The purchase is part of Apple's ongoing effort to invest in more original content, as well as compete with streaming services like Netflix and Amazon Prime. With the acquisition of Palm Springs, Apple has made it clear that they are serious about creating an impressive library of content. It remains to be seen what other purchases Apple will make in the future, but it's clear that they have their sights set on becoming a major player in the entertainment industry.

To begin forgiving yourself, admit that you messed up or made a mistake. Making mistakes is part of being human and no one is exempt from it. As soon as you admit your mistake, you are on the way to forgiveness. After you have admitted your mistake, you are ready for the second step in the forgiveness process. In the second step, you must apologize to the other person or people for the mistake you made. If it is your child or spouse, tell them how much you love them and apologize. If it is a colleague or friend, tell them how much they mean to you and apologize. Third, once you have said you are sorry, make it up to the person you wronged. Do something kind or nice for them. Write a note. Send them a card. Offer to take them out to dinner or to a movie. The goal is to do something nice for the person and let them know that you are sorry. After you have made amends with the person or people you wronged, the fourth step is to forgive yourself. Write a letter to yourself and tell yourself what you did wrong. Apologize to yourself for the mistakes you made. Tell yourself that you will do better and not make the same mistake again. After you have written the letter to yourself, burn it. Then throw the ashes in the toilet. This is a symbolic way to let go of your mistake. It is a way to wash away your sins. When you flush the ashes down the toilet, you are washing away your mistakes and cleansing yourself of the wrongdoing. The last step in the forgiveness process is to accept yourself. Forgive yourself for the mistakes you made. Know that you are human and that you will make mistakes again. As long as you are living, you will make mistakes. Forgive yourself, accept yourself and move forward. Remember, we are all human. Forgiveness is a process. There is no quick fix for mistakes. You have to work through them and come out the other side. Be kind to yourself. Be kind to others. Know that you are worthy of forgiveness and that you are loved.

Immigration has a profound impact on cultural diversity. When people from different countries and cultures come together, they bring their own unique traditions, languages, and perspectives. This can lead to a richer and more vibrant society, as people learn from each other and share their experiences.

One of the most visible impacts of immigration is the increased diversity of languages spoken in a country. In the United States, for example, there are over 300 different languages spoken. This linguistic diversity can be a challenge, but it can also be a great asset. It allows people from different backgrounds to communicate with each other and learn about each other's cultures.

Another impact of immigration is the increased availability of ethnic food. In the United States, there are now restaurants serving food from all over the world. This allows people to experience different cultures without having to travel. It can also help to break down stereotypes and prejudices, as people learn more about each other's cultures.

Immigration can also have a positive impact on the economy. Immigrants often bring new skills and talents to their new countries. They can also start businesses and create jobs. This can help to boost the economy and create a more prosperous society.

Of course, immigration can also have some negative impacts. One challenge is that it can lead to increased competition for jobs and resources. This can make it more difficult for people to find work and support their families. Another challenge is that immigration can lead to increased crime rates. This is because immigrants are often more likely to be poor and live in poverty-stricken areas, which are more prone to crime.

Overall, the impact of immigration on cultural diversity is complex and multifaceted. There are both positive and negative impacts, and the overall effect depends on a variety of factors. However, there is no doubt that immigration has a profound impact on the societies in which it occurs.

In conclusion, immigration has a significant impact on cultural diversity. It can lead to a richer and more vibrant society, but it can also pose challenges. It is important to weigh the potential benefits and drawbacks of immigration before making policy decisions.

Car-free cities are becoming increasingly popular as the world becomes more environmentally conscious. These cities are those where cars are either completely banned or heavily discouraged, and people are encouraged to use alternative modes of transportation such as walking, cycling, or public transportation. The idea of car-free cities has been around for decades, but it has only become a realistic possibility in recent years with the rise of urbanization and the increasing number of people living in cities. In this essay, I will explore the benefits of car-free cities and argue for their implementation in urban areas around the world.

One of the main benefits of car-free cities is a reduction in air pollution. Cars are one of the biggest sources of air pollution in cities, and their numbers have been steadily increasing in recent years. Car-free cities can help to reduce this problem by eliminating the need for cars altogether. By removing cars from the streets, cities can significantly reduce emissions of harmful gases, including carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter.

Another benefit of car-free cities is a reduction in traffic congestion. Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities around the world, and it can result in lost time, increased stress, and decreased productivity. Car-free cities can help to reduce traffic congestion by encouraging people to use alternative modes of transportation. By reducing the number of cars on the roads, cities can reduce the number of vehicles causing congestion and provide a more efficient transportation system.

Car-free cities also promote physical activity, which has numerous health benefits. Walking and cycling are great forms of exercise that can help to improve cardiovascular fitness, tone muscles, and boost overall health. By encouraging people to walk or cycle instead of driving, car-free cities can promote a healthier lifestyle for their residents. Additionally, walking and cycling are often faster than driving, especially in densely populated areas, so people can arrive at their destination more quickly.

Car-free cities can also have economic benefits. The cost of owning a car can be high, especially when considering maintenance costs, insurance, and fuel. Many people find that it is more economical to use alternative modes of transportation, especially when these options are easily accessible and convenient. By promoting alternative transportation options, car-free cities can encourage people to choose more cost-effective options, leading to increased financial stability for households.

In conclusion, car-free cities offer numerous benefits, including improved air quality, reduced traffic congestion, improved health outcomes, and increased economic stability. While the idea of car-free cities may seem radical, it is becoming increasingly practical in our modern world. Cities around the world should consider implementing car-free measures to improve the quality of life for their residents and create a more sustainable future.

In Arthurian legend, Avalon became associated with Glastonbury Tor when monks at Glastonbury Abbey claimed to have discovered the bones of King Arthur and his queen. What is more certain is that Glastonbury was an important religious centre by 700 and claims to be "the oldest above-ground Christian church in the World" situated "in the mystical land of Avalon." The claim is based on dating the founding of the community of monks at AD 63, the year of the legendary visit of Joseph of Arimathea, who was supposed to have brought the Holy Grail. During the Middle Ages there were also important religious sites at Woodspring Priory and Muchelney Abbey. The present Diocese of Bath and Wells covers Somerset - with the exception of the Parish of Abbots Leigh with Leigh Woods in North Somerset - and a small area of Dorset. The Episcopal seat of the Bishop of Bath and Wells is now in the Cathedral Church of Saint Andrew in the city of Wells, having previously been at Bath Abbey. Before the English Reformation, it was a Roman Catholic diocese; the county now falls within the Roman Catholic Diocese of Clifton. The Benedictine monastery Saint Gregory's Abbey, commonly known as Downside Abbey, is at Stratton-on-the-Fosse, and the ruins of the former Cistercian Cleeve Abbey are near the village of Washford.

The ethics of human enhancement and biohacking have been a topic of debate for many years. As technology advances, the possibilities for altering our biological makeup become more and more apparent. From genetic editing to implanting microchips, these new techniques raise questions about what it means to be human and what the implications are for society as a whole.

One of the most controversial aspects of human enhancement is the use of genetic editing. CRISPR technology has made it possible to edit our DNA with unprecedented precision, allowing for the correction of genetic disorders and the creation of designer babies. However, this technology also raises concerns about eugenics and the potential for creating a genetically superior race. Additionally, there is a risk of unintended consequences, such as the creation of new diseases or the alteration of traits that are important for human diversity.

Another form of biohacking involves the implantation of microchips in the human body. These chips can be used for a variety of purposes, such as monitoring health status or providing access to buildings and computers. However, there are also concerns about privacy and security, as well as the potential for abuse by governments or corporations. For example, if microchips were required for employment or financial transactions, they could be used to monitor and control individuals' behavior.

Another ethical concern is the potential for creating a "digital divide" between those who choose to enhance themselves and those who do not. As technology advances, it may become increasingly difficult for individuals without enhancements to compete in the job market or other aspects of society. This could lead to social inequality and discrimination against non-enhanced individuals.

In conclusion, the ethics of human enhancement and biohacking are complex and multifaceted. While there are potential benefits to these technologies, there are also significant ethical concerns that must be addressed. It is crucial that we consider the implications of these technologies not only for individuals but for society as a whole. As we continue to explore the possibilities of human enhancement, it will be important to maintain a dialogue about the ethical implications of these technologies and to ensure that they are used in a responsible and equitable manner.

Motivated by biochemical reaction networks, a generalization of the classical secant condition for the stability analysis of cyclic interconnected commensurate fractional-order systems is provided. The main result presents a sufficient system for modeling and simulation of the complex asymmetry between macroscopic changes in the synthesis flow rate and chemical properties. This leads to a reasonable approximation of equilibrium (Fig. 1). A multi-strategic solid phase with low stoichiometry in the free float reaction state was also proposed. Most of these models are based on kinetic data from multiple initiators, which are not statistically significant but can be deduced through the experiments performed with the classical secant conditions. Discussion The classical cycle-dependent family of cycle-independent types of images consists mainly of two groups: finite factorial and parametric ones. The classical sine wave set that is considered to represent the equilibrium framework belongs to an approach that involves the substitution of time-series waves for distance-transforming films. It has been shown that asymmetric forms of image composition are very important factor influencing the stability of photoimaging systems according to the symmetry of the method. In order to solve this problem, we investigated the use of an eighth fundamental system as one example. We show that the symmetries of the state of pure disordered bulk photosensitive components function differently depending upon their symmetry, namely, they do not depend on the number of photons per unit quantity (PQ) and they have two independent functions - the first is the potassium ionization function (KI), corresponding to the decomposition of electrons, and the second is the shifty spin function. These parameters of symmetry may play key roles in the optimal dispersion ratio in photoimaging systems; therefore it is essential to define a class of superconducting states known as "coupled" systems. The combination of the three functional domains of Coulombism, Shannon's law and nonlinearity makes such a class a reliable choice for any type of light source intended to convert visible light into infrared rays, or to store information about energy transfer in materials used for semiconductor processing.

Have you tried good cheese curds? That'll answer your question. I'm not far from Canada,Canadian winters are terribly harsh. Only those with several extra layers of fat can survive a Canadian winter. While Eskimos have natural fat layers to survive the cold, most Caucasian Canadians do not. In order to adapt and acclimate, Canadians have taken to consuming cheese curd and lager beer. Cheese curd when eaten alongside Moosehead and LaBatts beers creates several layers of fat in the Caucasian Canadian which enables them to survive the brutal winters.', "It is less about being a northern state, and more about being a cheese state. States like Wisconsin, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, New York, and Vermont were typically big cheese producers, so cheese was cheap and available enough to be a bar snack. Even though cheese production has shifted to other states in recent decades, they haven't had time to develop the same sort of cheese culture.,Because they are delicious, and dairy is quite common in some northern states around the Great Lakes and Canada.', "It all has to do with the harsh winters. Cheese curds are essentially fried cheese which is a great way to pack a ton of caloric intake into a small meal. This gives advantages two-fold: 1. The human body tends to adjust to the cold weather by increasing metabolism (which requires many calories from cheese curds) to internally generate heat. This is why 40 degrees Fahrenheit is shorts and t shirt weather after a long winter. Everyone's body has adjusted to the cold. 2. The large caloric intake also produces a layer of blubber around the body to act as extra insulation to hold in heat. This layer of blubber is the same that allows other mammals such as Arctic seals swimming in water to withstand extreme cold temperatures

Car-free cities are becoming increasingly popular in many parts of the world, and for good reason. With the rise of air pollution and climate change, the traditional reliance on cars has become unsustainable. In this essay, I will explore the advantages of limiting car usage in cities, based on ideas and information from multiple sources.

First, reducing car use has a significant positive impact on air and noise pollution. Cars are one of the primary sources of air pollution in cities, as they emit harmful chemicals and particulate matter into the air. By reducing the number of cars on the road, cities can significantly decrease their levels of air pollution, improving the overall health of their citizens. Additionally, noise pollution has become a major problem in many cities, as the constant roar of traffic can be extremely distressing. Car-free cities offer a peaceful and quiet environment, improved social interaction, and a more efficient and accessible transportation system.

Second, car-free cities can be a powerful tool in addressing climate change. The transportation sector is responsible for approximately 23% of global greenhouse gas emissions, and cities are a major part of this sector. By reducing the number of cars on the road, cities can significantly decrease their carbon footprint and contribute to a more sustainable future. Furthermore, car-free cities often encourage the use of public transportation and cycling, which produce even fewer emissions.

Third, car-free cities can improve traffic flow and reduce congestion. Cars are notorious for their unpredictable and often slow-moving nature, leading to traffic jams and congestion. By removing cars from the roads, cities can improve their traffic flow and reduce congestion. This can lead to increased productivity, as people can get to work and other destinations more quickly and efficiently. Additionally, cities can use the space previously occupied by cars to build more parks, green spaces, and other amenities that benefit their citizens.

In conclusion, the advantages of limiting car usage in cities are numerous. Car-free cities can improve air and noise pollution, address climate change, improve traffic flow and reduce congestion, and contribute to a more sustainable and livable future. As citizens and policymakers, we must recognize the importance of this issue and take action to create car-free cities that benefit us all.

Heterosexual, or Straight: An attraction to the opposite sex. Bisexual - Attraction to both sexes. Homosexual or Gay - Attraction to the same sex. Pansexual, or Omnisexual - Liking someone no-matter what their gender is. Asexual - Having no attraction to either sex. Polysexual - Liking more than one sex but not identified as bisexual because that implies there are only two genders or sexes. Since I am the first person to graduate from high school in my family, I am a bit unfortunate because I do not know what to expect as college comes to mind. Being that, I try to seek the resources that are available, for example talking to my high school counselors or mentors that are available to help me. It is still challenging because I am not able to talk to my parents about the college process because they would not understand. While growing up, the first language I learned and spoke was Spanish. My parents were not familiar with the English language therefore, I was not acquainted with. Whenever I started school, I noticed that almost everyone around me spoke English and the homework I was assigned was in English. That is when all the challenges began flowing in. I had difficulties doing my homework and received little support from my parents since they did not understand the material. The only resources I found useful were from the teachers at school since they were teaching the subject. There were times I just wanted to give up everything, but I realized that I was not the only one struggling with this problem, and that if I would learn English it would be like finding a key to the door of endless possibilities. Being the oldest in my family turned out to be difficult because I was the one in charge of my siblings whenever my mother was not available. I was responsible for them and made sure they were doing fine. Going home, I had various responsibilities waiting for me, they were to do my homework, my chores, and take care of my siblings if my parents were not home. While school was expecting me to do my work my parents were expecting me to be responsible for my siblings at home. Going to college will be a big step I will take towards a successful future; it will change my life because I will take advantage of having the privilege of pursuing a higher education and gaining further knowledge in life. It will be a dream I have always wanted to accomplish with the hard work and strength I have put towards my education. Being that my parents did not pursue higher education, and have to perform jobs that pay little money, I want to succeed and not follow their footsteps because I want to have a chance to maintain a stable career upon completing graduation and provide for my family. I believe in the American dream. Would really appreciate your help. Thanks.

Image segmentation is one of the most fundamental tasks of computer vision. In many practical applications, it is essential to properly evaluate the reliability of individual segmentation results. In this study, we propose a novel framework for determining the statistical significance of segmentation results in the form of p -values. Specifically, we utilize a statistical hypothesis test for determining the difference between the object region and the background region. This problem is challenging because the difference can be deceptively large (called segmentation bias) due to the adaptation of the segmentation algorithm to the data. To overcome this difficulty, we introduce a statistical approach called selective inference, and develop a framework for computing valid p -values in which segmentation bias is properly accounted for. Although the proposed framework is potentially applicable to various segmentation algorithms, here we focus on graph-cut- and threshold-based segmentation algorithms, and develop two specific methods for computing valid p -values for the segmentation results obtained by these algorithms. We prove the theoretical validity of these two methods and demonstrate their practicality by applying them to the segmentation of medical images.

Her decision was linked to a French inquiry into claims that her centrist MoDem party wrongly used EU funds to pay party workers. She is a former MEP. Her party is allied to the president's La Republique en Marche (LREM) party. Ms Goulard is the second leading figure in President Emmanuel Macron's cabinet to leave ahead of a reshuffle. One of the president's closest confidants, Richard Ferrand, announced his resignation from the cabinet on Monday after becoming ensnared in allegations that he had used insider information to secure a lucrative property deal for his wife while he was head of a mutual health insurance fund. While both ministers have denied any wrongdoing, their cases threatened to overshadow a president who ran on a ticket of fighting political sleaze. Mr Macron has already announced details of his bill to clean up politics, which involves stopping politicians hiring members of their own family, a ban of up to 10 years for MPs and senators convicted of corruption or fraud, and reform of party financing. The man who presented the proposals is MoDem leader Francois Bayrou, the justice minister whose party won 42 seats in Sunday's elections in areas that went uncontested by LREM. Mr Macron's party secured a majority in parliament with 308 of the 577 seats. In a statement, Ms Goulard said that the president's commitment to restoring confidence in public office "must take precedence over any personal considerations." As the inquiry continued, she wanted to be in a position to show her "good faith," she said. The president's allies have voiced confidence in Mr Bayrou, despite the embarrassment of the fake jobs inquiry. "Mr Bayrou is destined to stay in the government," said Prime Minister Edouard Philippe. The justice minister refused to comment on Ms Goulard's resignation on Tuesday, describing it as a personal decision. He has also insisted that party workers have never taken on fake jobs as assistants to MoDem MEPs in the European Parliament. Many saw the president's hand in Ms Goulard's resignation, reports the BBC's Hugh Schofield. She was one of five women given top jobs in the Macron cabinet last month and accompanied the president on his visit to Mali last month, his first trip outside Europe. Doubts have also been raised about the future of another MoDem politician, European Affairs Minister Marielle de Sarnez. Like Ms Goulard, she is part of the Paris prosecutor's inquiry.

This paper develops an interference aware design for cooperative hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) assisted non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme for large-scale device-to-device (D2D) networks. Specifically, interference aware rate selection (IARS) and hybrid multiplexing are proposed to optimize the HARQ and NOMA techniques, respectively, for energy-efficient and reliable D2D communication. The HARQ and NOMA techniques can be used in a variety of scenarios, including in-band shared access, underlay, and overlay. However, HARQ combined with NOMA does not perform well due to the coexistence of the two techniques in a single link. To this end, IARS is proposed to select the transmission rate based on the transmission interval, power, and the interference level, such that the HARQ performance is not affected by the interference of other links. IARS-assisted HARQ (IHARQ) is designed for downlink NOMA transmission. Since the HARQ technique is not considered in the uplink NOMA transmission, IHARQ is complemented with a power allocation algorithm, which jointly optimizes the transmit power and the uplink HARQ multiplexing order. Moreover, IHARQ is also extended for a multi-user scenario and combined with a novel NOMA-based power allocation (NPA). The proposed NPA-assisted IHARQ (NIHARQ) is designed for uplink NOMA transmission. Simulation results show that the proposed IHARQ and NIHARQ schemes outperform the conventional NOMA schemes, such as the non-selective power allocation (NSPA), transmit power control (TPC), and hybrid automatic repeat request (HARQ) -aided adaptive power allocation (HAPA), in terms of throughput, energy efficiency, and reliability. This work was supported in part by the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) grant funded by the Korean government (MEST) (No. NRF-2012M2A7A1037610).

Historians disagree on what the relationship was between the Ming court and Tibet and whether or not Ming China had sovereignty over Tibet. Van Praag writes that Chinese court historians viewed Tibet as an independent foreign tributary and had little interest in Tibet besides a lama-patron relationship. The historian Tsepon W. D. Shakabpa supports van Praag's position. However, Wang Jiawei and Nyima Gyaincain state that these assertions by van Praag and Shakabpa are "fallacies."

Devtron is a platform for operationalizing and maintaining applications on Kubernetes. It features a zero-code software delivery workflow, multi-cloud deployment, an application debugging dashboard, operational insights, and more. Screenshots are below: Distributed computing is one of the most common use cases related to DevOps strategy adoption. By moving away from costly hardware and network infrastructure components in favor of cloud services, companies can consolidate costs while improving software quality and security. This allows them to reduce their overhead and increase flexibility as they expand or scale their IT function. With that, DevOps has become a key differentiator between companies with highly secure, reliable products and those who don't. For example, you won't see an enterprise security provider like FireEye or Palo Alto Networks using cloud services because it's too expensive, instead, they will choose cheaper cloud providers such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) or Google Cloud Platform (GCP). In this post, I'll show you how to deploy your own private Kubernetes cluster and get started with Kubernetes Deployment Service (KDS), which we're going to use to build our first application. You'll also learn about Docker and its container orchestration scheme, how K8s makes deployments easy, and finally how to manage your PaaS environment with Kubernetes KMS. All these topics are great ways for you to get comfortable doing DevOps inside your company through a sort of hands-on, learning process. We hope that these posts will help you better understand what's required to start building and deploying applications in the cloud. Let's dive right into things!

Terra preta (black earth), which is distributed over large areas in the Amazon forest, is now widely accepted as a product of indigenous soil management. The development of this fertile imagination has been enjoyed by indigenous people throughout Central America and Latin America for centuries, but it was only possible because of the use of modern methods such as irrigation systems that were developed during the last century. The landowner claims that Terra preta solves problems caused by the lack of drainage due to lack of water resources; hence the significance of its importance thanks largely to its climate influence on tropical rainforests and forest degradation from deforestation. Terra preta produces nearly 60 less carbon dioxide than terrestrial forests achieve, enabling it to produce crops with low emissions while providing far more storage space than other forms of agriculture. Terra preta holds limited water supply, however: according to the Ministry of Environment, this means less flow compared to terrestrial forest cover per acre since much higher water availability requires greater volumes of groundwater recharge rather than water deprivation levels have been achieved via other diversions like the Atlantic Ocean or the Pacific Ocean. Terra preta also supports sound agriculture through access to water sources besides providing habitat for native birds that rely upon forest animals around it, including hippopotamus and camels, among others. By contrast, Terra pretas constitute about 2 of the total agricultural production in Brazil today. Terra preta remains endemic to the region just a few kilometers away from the Amazon River Valley - the first Amazonian forest to be established over 200 years ago when the river was planted with palm trees. Early indigenous peoples viewed Terra preta with suspicion despite their knowledge of the jungle's complex ecosystem conditions resulting from extensive deforestation. Despite this negative perception and their struggle against the logging industry, Terra preta continues to represent an important example of sustainable forestry practices towards the end of the era of fossil fuels and deforestation. Terra preta covers approximately 20 million hectares globally and accounts for 80 of Brazilian forests. In 2019, Marsados, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Venezuela began using Terra preta whereas Brazil and Chile will begin using Terra preta within one year. However, Terra preta does not grow enough to support conventional plantations yet. According to scientists, Terra preta contributes 1 to Bolivia's GDP annually, 15 to Brazil's GDP, 10 to Peru's GDP and 29 to Argentina's GDP - in addition to producing 30 of Bolivia's natural gas exports. Terra preta can provide sufficient growth opportunities relative to others unless it becomes increasingly obsolete after 2035-50 million hectares are replaced by the production of biofuels and petroleum products across the globe. Terra preta follows the Amazon Basin's dominant position between deforestation risks 10C as well as risks associated with deforestation risk 100Cs, for instance due to excessive flooding parts of Peru and Bolivia cannot sustain themselves without sea level rise. This article was originally published at Climate Change Science Review.

In the heart of a bustling city, a person might feel disconnected from nature, yearning for the calm and serenity that comes with being surrounded by greenery and fresh air. Outdoor living, or the connection between people and nature, is a concept that can be experienced in various ways, even in the most urban environments. By embracing the outdoor lifestyle, city dwellers can reap a multitude of benefits, from health improvements to a deeper appreciation for the natural world.

One of the most fundamental aspects of outdoor living is the integration of natural elements into urban spaces. This can be achieved through the incorporation of green roofs, parks, and greenways, which not only enhance the aesthetic appeal of the city but also provide essential habitats for local wildlife. Additionally, urban gardens and community farms offer opportunities for residents to engage in gardening and farming, fostering a sense of responsibility and stewardship towards the environment.

Another critical aspect of outdoor living is the promotion of physical activity and exercise. Urban parks, playgrounds, and recreational areas provide opportunities for people to engage in various activities such as jogging, biking, or simply relaxing and soaking up the sun. This increased physical activity not only improves overall health and well-being but also contributes to a stronger sense of community as people interact with one another in shared spaces.

Moreover, outdoor living encourages mindfulness and a deeper appreciation for the natural world. Engaging in activities such as bird watching, hiking, or simply observing the changing seasons can lead to a greater understanding and respect for the environment. This heightened awareness can, in turn, foster a sense of personal responsibility and a commitment to preserving the natural environment.

The benefits of outdoor living are not limited to the individual level; they also extend to the broader community. Green spaces have been shown to reduce air pollution and mitigate the urban heat island effect, improving the overall air quality and climate of the city. Furthermore, well-maintained parks and greenways can boost property values and enhance the attractiveness of a neighborhood, drawing in new residents and stimulating economic growth.

In conclusion, outdoor living is a concept that can be embraced by city dwellers in various ways, from integrating natural elements into urban spaces to engaging in physical activities and fostering a deeper appreciation for the environment. By embracing these practices, people can reap a multitude of benefits, from improved health and well-being to a stronger sense of community and environmental stewardship.

Your brain has 3 basic parts, correspond to evolutionary stages and moods.... (I'm roughly paraphrasing from Carl Sagan's'Dragons of Eden brainstemlizard brain: fear and lust, no forward planning. midbraindog brain: mood without processing, ie religious fervor. forebrainhuman brain: high level processing, math problems. The proposal is your forebrain spends all day riding the more primitive components, and shuts down at night and the more primitive components come out to play. The lizard is trying to make sense of things that don't make sense, and it looks really strange when your forebrain manages to take some of that back to waking land. Check out the Sagan book I mentioned for more.,Based on my own understanding of how dreams work, your brain is putting together tons of random images and thoughts together all at once (from whatever is currently on your mind or things that have happened to you recently). It would be like taking a bunch of random clips from a movie and throwing them all together to make a scene and trying to make sense of it all. It might come out seeming pretty weird.','Also could do with your diet. Take a vitamin B Complex pill before bed and get ready for some real trippy colourful dreams!','When using melatonin pills to help me switch from night shifts to days I get some really odd dream sequences.

With many, many places to choose from, I will go elsewhere. Just dropped in for a beer and to check the place out for the first time. The bartender, walking past without stopping or offering any other greeting says, I need your ID's out, please. Immediately conveying that I was merely an inconvenience in her busy day was a horrible first impression. The bar restaurant wasn't even full at the time, a weeknight around 7pm. Not that this would have even been a justification. This person conveyed that they barely cared that I had just entered the business. She came back and reviewed our ID's, I ordered my one beer, and the mrs said she just wanted to drink water. The beverages were brought back, and I offered money immediately, without asking the cost. I got my change back, and discovered by looking at the receipt that they charge 75 cents for a glass of water. Seriously. I was a bit stunned. I have been in more than a few bars in Vegas, and do not ever recall being charged for tap water.

DateTime: Saturday - 7:30pm Occasion: Dinner with daddy and little brother Party of: Three Location: Typical Chinese restaurant. Simple decor. Not the cleanest Ordered: Westlake Beef Soup, Flamebroiled Pepper-Beef Steak, Ginger Chicken, and Seafood-Tofu claypot Total incl gratuity: Expensive. Definitely gone down-hill. And quite simply put, not worth it. The only thing worth mentioning was the soup. The pepper beef steak was sliced way too large and quite difficult to chew. The ginger chicken was terribly dry. And I wasn't interested in taking another bite of the seafood tofu claypot. To top it off, each entree ran 12 - 18. 60 for four entrees at a Chinese restaurant?? Definitely not worth it it! I've typically gone here for lunch and ordered noodles. Now I'm scared and likely not to return. I'm going to stick with pho in Chinatown from now on. Fellow yelpers: any suggestions on other better Chinese restaurants in the area?;)

I was about 9 years old when I had just been cleared to leave the hospital as I placed the new crutches; I had received as a result of injuring my hip, underneath my arms and began hobbling our way to the exit. As we went along we passed by many examination rooms, labs and patients. About 10 steps away from the exit I saw a child about the same age as me back then pass by on a stretcher, the boy had no hair on his body whatsoever. My mom saw me looking at him with a puzzled expression on my face and told me that he was sick. I asked her what kind of sick, and she said he had a very bad sickness that is called a terminal disease. I found out later when I got home that the terminal disease she was talking about was cancer. Furthermore, I've had a love for science for as long as I could ever remember and can't imagine life without it. When I saw my first science project comprised of baking soda being mixed with vinegar I was so amazed and mesmerized that I knew from that point then that I'd want to work with science for the rest of my life. I've also had quite a few driving forces in my life pushing me toward science. The first and most influential force would be my mother. She's worked her whole life in science ranging from being a pharmacist to being a nurse. I'd always see her come home with all types of charts full of information that I'd try to decode and would eventually end up asking her about. I'd ask so many questions till the point that she'd fall asleep and to this very day I still do. She took me to work with her one day, and I was amazed at the amount of sincerity and precision she put into everything from administrating medicine to just talking to her patients. Another influential force in my life would be Doctor Vivien Thomas. When I first heard how Doctor Thomas rose above poverty and racism at all odds to become a cardiac surgeon I knew I had to learn more. After some research I discovered that he was the man behind the Blalock-Taussig shunt, the life-saving procedure that cures the blue baby syndrome. With inspirational role models such as Doctor Thomas and my very own mother I hope to be able to make a difference in the medical world and become just as influential to others people as they are to me. (432 words) Please critique and give helpful revisions :D

Sports have an incredible power to bring people together and foster social connections in a community. Whether it's a local youth soccer team or a national pride in the country's Olympic athletes, shared interests in athletic competition can transcend differences and cultivate cooperation. There are few things that so many people, from all walks of life, find enjoyment and meaning in like they do sports.

From a young age, playing on little league teams or school sports lays the foundation for important life lessons. Kids learn what it means to be part of a group, working towards a common goal which requires coordination, perseverance and good sportsmanship. They build friendships with teammates and rivals alike, gaining exposure to diverse backgrounds. Even if an individual doesn't have athletic talent, being part of the team is what's emphasized. This nurtures values like inclusion, collaboration and fairness. 

As kids grow into adults, recreational community sports leagues continue providing a social structure and shared activity for bonding. Local football or bowling nights are a consistent way for neighbors and colleagues to connect regularly outside of work or family obligations. Whether the competition is intense or laid back, the fun is in the camaraderie of cheering each other on and sharing in the ups and downs together. Professional franchises also galvanize civic pride, giving residents of a town or city a public symbol to rally behind.

On a national level, major sporting events like the World Cup or Olympics occupy a unique place to stir patriotism while promoting peace. Though countries compete vigorously for medals and trophies, the overarching message conveyed through these mass global spectacles is one of international understanding and goodwill between nations. Visiting fans experience glimpses into foreign cultures through the universal language of play. Shared joy in victory or sympathy in defeat helps break down barriers between peoples from different lands.

While sports at their core are entertainment, their social function runs much deeper in binding communities. Whether bringing youth together in character-building programs, bolstering social bonds between neighbors, or fostering global fellowship, they forge links across boundaries. In a fragmented world, sports remain one of the few realms that can consistently gather people and kindle the spirit of unity. Their role in promoting social cohesion is invaluable and will surely continue far into the future.

Researchers have found that suicide among lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender youth (LGBT) is comparatively higher than among the general population. Many high school students who are gay lack the social support much needed in these delicate and emotionally grueling teenage years. Many high schools do not offer support groups for these individuals and parents are often oblivious of what their children are going through. These students are in constant fear of being taunted or harassed. Some would rather conform to the norm, then be disliked for the sexual preferences. High school can be some of the worst years for these students; they have virtually no support and lack the abilities to deal with these social problems, thus, turning to suicide as a solution to their problems. I know how difficult life is when you are gay because, I am homosexual and accepting my sexuality was very difficult. All of my life, society has taught me that being gay is wrong. However, in my teenage years, I knew that there was something different about my sexual preferences. I denied it for many years, I practically lived in fear. When I revealed my sexuality to a close friend, she betrayed me and told everyone I knew. Many of my friends abandoned me; I was alone, without any support or understanding. I have experienced difficulty in finding new friends and people who were accepting of my homosexuality. I was talked about, criticized, and ridiculed, by many people I knew. Many of my peers were in fear of even being in the locker-room with me while they were undressing. As a result of this, I kept my sexuality hidden from my new friends. My junior year, I finally accepted myself. I was fed up with pretending to be someone who I wasn't. I came out to everyone I knew and not surprisingly, I lost many new friends; however, I was shocked to see that many of my friends became accepting. Furthermore, I even influenced some of my peers to reveal their sexuality to their friends. At first many people behaved awkward around me, especially my basketball teammates, but with time they became comfortable around me. It felt so good to finally be honest with others, but most importantly honest with myself. This experience with my sexual identity has been a rough process, but I learned that in order to have others accept me; I need to be more accepting of others and their personal beliefs. Everyone is different and this is what contributes to the diversity of our world. We learn from people of different cultures and religions, but in order to learn from others we must be willing and unbiased.

Product Distribution Options Essay

The selection of the most effective product distribution channels is among the most challenging tasks for new businesses. Even if the goods are to be sold using innovative technology and have no analogs in the market, the distribution strategies should be planned thoroughly. The example of a new home tooth brushing system that does not require the use of toothpaste involves a range of potential problems linked to distribution.

Most importantly, giving too much power to intermediaries and product distributors in the mentioned case are associated with the threat of new competitors or even fake products. At the same time, selling the toothbrush to clients requires the presence of effective advertising materials. It is because the brush that performs its functions without toothpaste will become popular only if consumers change their years-long habits and are fully aware of its benefits. To address the listed problems, it is possible to implement a multi-channel approach and sell the toothbrush both directly and with retailers’ help (Kotler and Armstrong, p. 308). The use of two strategies will allow appealing to different customer segments and taking younger and older clients’ characteristics into account.

The combination of different ways to sell the invented toothbrush will help to maximize profits and create a strong brand image. The first strategy will involve online advertising and direct sales with the help of the producer’s official website (Kotler and Armstrong, p. 308). It is planned that this approach to distribution will help to attract young customers who value time-consuming options and are digitally literate. Older people may have negative attitudes toward buying products on the Internet or simply distrust online shops, and this is why retailers’ help is required. Collaboration with retailers will significantly increase the product’s market penetration rates and allow selling it in local household appliances shops. Alternatively, building strong partner relationships with the largest teleshopping companies will solidify the outcomes of online advertising efforts and further improve brand recognition.

Work Cited

Kotler, Philip, and Gary Armstrong. Principles of Marketing . 14th ed., Prentice Hall, 2011.

It depends on what part of your head is hurting. If it's the forehead, that's usually dehydration or the forehead sinus. If it's behind the eyes, it's usually the sternocleidomastoid, or the muscle that sticks out on the front of your neck when you turn your head. If it's on the side of your head, it's the scalenes, or the muscles along the sides of your neck. If it's in the back of your head, it's usually the levator scapulae, or the muscle that lifts your shoulders up to your ears.,Headache pain mostly is not like pain in other parts of the body. Some headache pain is from sore muscles. Most of it is from the arteries that supply the brain. The brain itself cannot sense pain - it has no nerve endings to detect pain - but many arteries do enter the brain to bring blood, and those arteries do have nerve endings. Headaches have to do with sudden changes in the size of brain arteries. Brain arteries are always dilating and constricting in order to regulate the amount of blood that goes to the brain. This process gets fouled up in some headaches, and the arteries constrict tightly for a few minutes, then dilate excessively. When the arteries dilate excessively they get swollen and inflamed, and their nerve endings report this as pain. Finally, headaches have to do with an alteration in the way your brain is paying attention to pain. During a headache, all things are perceived as more painful than at other times - including the headache itself. This process may actually be important for the generation of headaches in the first place.

Driverless cars are becoming increasingly popular as technology continues to improve. These vehicles use a combination of sensors, cameras, and artificial intelligence to navigate roads and perform tasks that typically require human input. While some people are excited about the prospect of owning a car that doesn't require a driver, others have concerns about the safety and reliability of these vehicles. 

One of the main advantages of driverless cars is the potential for increased safety on the roads. Human error is a leading cause of car accidents, and driverless cars can help to reduce the number of accidents that occur due to distracted or impaired drivers. Additionally, these vehicles can be programmed to obey traffic laws and reduce the risk of accidents caused by speeding or reckless driving. 

However, there are also concerns about the safety of driverless cars. Some people worry that these vehicles are prone to technical failures or glitches that could put drivers and passengers at risk. Additionally, there are concerns about the liability of car manufacturers or insurance companies if a driverless car is involved in an accident. It is important for manufacturers and insurance companies to address these concerns and ensure that driverless cars are as safe as possible. 

Another concern about driverless cars is the potential for job loss. As cars become more autonomous, there may be less demand for drivers, which could lead to job loss and economic instability in the transportation industry. However, there are also opportunities for new jobs to be created in the development and maintenance of these vehicles. 

Overall, driverless cars have the potential to change the way we think about transportation and improve safety on the roads. However, it is important for manufacturers, policymakers, and society as a whole to address the concerns associated with these vehicles and ensure that they are safe and reliable.

In this paper, we consider a novel cache-enabled heterogeneous network (HetNet), where macro base stations (BSs) with traditional sub-6 GHz are overlaid by dense millimeter wave (mmWave) pico BSs. These pico BSs are operated by a centralized Cloud-radio access network (C-RAN) architecture and are assumed to be co-located with small form factor femto BSs. We consider a novel co-channel access scheme, called opportunistic (OC), which adopts a two-level access mechanism. Under OC, both macro and pico BSs use different resource and time allocation schemes. A centralized resource allocation algorithm is proposed to solve a mixed sub-6 GHz and mmWave joint optimization problem, which jointly optimizes the power levels, sub-6 GHz and mmWave data rate allocations, and pico BS's transmit power levels. We derive closed-form expressions for the ergodic throughput of the proposed OC scheme and show that its performance is robust to the different assumptions on the imperfect channel state information (CSI) available at both macro and pico BSs. Numerical results show that the proposed OC scheme can outperform other schemes under various assumptions on the imperfect CSI, by significantly improving the system spectral efficiency. X. Wan and Y. Wang and D. Zheng and X. Xu, "Opportunistic Co-Channel Access for Cache-Enabled Heterogeneous Networks," IEEE Transactions on Communications, vol. 64, no. 9, pp. 3066-3079, September 2016. I ordered the Baja Burger. I said Baja Burger. When the food came, it looked like chicken. I said, I ordered a burger. The waitress replied, It's a chicken burger. Being the reasonable person I am, I assumed I hadn't been paying attention (which has been known to happen) and wondered to myself why they'd put a'chicken burger' in the burger section. I mean, I read the description - it said nothing about being chicken. Whatever, it looked good so I chalked it up to me not paying attention and let it go. The'chicken burger' was delicious. So good. I was very pleased. The service was pretty slow, especially after we got our food. The hostess cleared our plates and we waited patiently - for who knows how long - for our waitress to come back by. She finally dropped the check, at which point we waited a while longer - long enough for me to take a leisurely trip to the restroom - before she finally came back by to retrieve the check and run my card. On the way to the restroom, I passed the kitchen where I saw the waitress either doing her sidework or checking out others' sidework. Either way, I had my answer as to why the service slowed to a crawl. Oh, and on that check was printed, Baja Chicken Sandwich. I checked the menu on my phone to make sure I wasn't losing my mind. I wasn't. I said burger.

He complained that Dawn Bowden referred to "Goebbels-like propaganda from the right-wing media" in a recent debate. Yesterday, Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns attended Prime Minister David Cameron's final cabinet meeting at 10 Downing Street. Cairns was one of the last ministers to emerge from the meeting and spoke briefly with reporters about the day's events. Cairns described the meeting as "emotional" and "reflective," as Cabinet members said their goodbyes to David Cameron, who is set to resign after six years as Prime Minister. "David Cameron gave a very powerful speech," Cairns said. "There was a lot of emotion in the room, particularly in the closing moments of the meeting." When asked about his own role in the government, Cairns praised the work of the Welsh Office and expressed optimism about the future. "I'm proud of the work we've done in Wales over the past few years," Cairns said. "We've made significant progress in attracting investment, creating jobs, and improving infrastructure. I'm confident that the next government will build on these successes and continue to support the people of Wales." Cairns declined to comment on speculation about his future in government, and instead deferred to the incoming Prime Minister. "We don't yet know who the next Prime Minister will be," Cairns said. "But whoever it is, they will have my full support and dedication to working for the people of Wales." Cameron's resignation comes after the UK's decision to leave the European Union in the "Brexit" referendum. The Prime Minister has said he will step down in October, and the Conservative Party is currently in the process of selecting a new leader to take over as Prime Minister.

It was 8:30am and Melissa had overslept. She was usually the first one up in her house, but today was different. Her alarm had gone off at 7 and she had pushed it off for another 5 minutes until it stopped buzzing. Before she knew it, it was already 8:30. Melissa jumped out of bed and started getting ready as quickly as possible. She dressed in record time and grabbed her backpack before running out the door. She ran to the bus stop, hoping that she would make it in time. Unfortunately, the bus had already left and she was too late. Melissa started walking towards school, feeling frustrated with herself for not getting up on time. She kept thinking about how embarrassing it would be to show up late to class. As she walked, she passed by a couple of stores and noticed something interesting in one of the windows - a bike! Melissa walked into the store and asked if she could buy the bike. The shopkeeper agreed and Melissa paid him with the last of her money. She hopped on the bike and pedalled as fast as she could. When Melissa arrived at school, she was relieved to find that she wasn't too late. She locked her bike up and went straight to class. As she walked in, the teacher smiled and said, "Good morning, Melissa. You made it just in time!" Melissa smiled back, thankful that she had made it to school on time. From then on, Melissa always made sure to set her alarm earlier so she wouldn't be late again.

Material: wool may be scratchier than cotton. Egyptian Cotton is cotton with a longer staple, which means a longer thread can be woven from one piece, which means there is more continuous fiber in the fabric. More continuous fiber means it's softer, more durable, and also more expensive. Fabric: Cotton is lightweight. Wool is very warm and soft and is usually used in winter. Insulation: Cotton absorbs moisture, which makes it cooler in summer and warmer in winter. Wool is very good at retaining heat, making it more appropriate for winter. Price: Cotton is less expensive than wool. Warmth: Wool is warm, cotton is cool. Breathability: Wool is warmer, but it is not very breathable. Cotton is a soft, fluffy staple fiber that grows in a boll around the seeds of the cotton plants of the genus Gossypium in the mallow family Malvaceae. The fiber is almost pure cellulose. Under natural conditions, the cotton bolls will tend to increase the dispersal of the seeds. The plant is a shrub native to tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including the Americas, Africa, and India. The greatest diversity of wild cotton species is found in Mexico, followed by Australia and Africa. Cotton was independently domesticated in the New Worlds. The fiber is most spun into yarn or thread and used to make a soft, breathable textile, which is the most widely used natural-fiber cloth in clothing today. The English name derives from the Arabic (al) qutn, which began to be used circa 1400 AD. Cotton has been spun, woven and dyed since prehistoric times. It clothed the people of ancient India, Egypt and China. Wool is the textile fiber obtained from sheep and certain other animals, including cashmere and mohair from goats, qiviut from muskoxen, from hide and fur clothing from bison, angora from rabbits, and other types of wool from camelids. Wool has several qualities that distinguish it from hair or fur: it is crimped, it is elastic, and it grows in staples (clusters). Wool's scaling and crimp make it easier to spin the fleece by helping the individual fibers attach to each other, so they stay together. Because of the crimp, wool fabrics have greater bulk than other textiles, and they hold air, which causes the fabric to retain heat. Insulation works both ways: Bedouins and Tuaregs use wool clothes to keep heat out and protect the body. Felting of wool occurs upon hammering or other mechanical agitation as the microscopic barbs on the surface of wool fibers hook together. Which type of underwear do you prefer? Which t-shirt is better?
