Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has revealed that he gave his players the chance to opt out of Monday night's match against Sunderland if they were too tired - but nobody wanted to. Klopp said that he was pleased with the way his side responded to the challenge of playing two games in quick succession, having beaten Chelsea 2-1 at Anfield on Saturday. And he praised the character of his players, who he said were fully committed to getting a result at the Stadium of Light. "We had a few players who were really tired after Saturday," Klopp told reporters. "So I asked them yesterday if they felt they could not play today, and nobody said 'no, I cannot play'. "That shows the character of the group. They all want to play, and that is a good sign." Liverpool eventually ran out 3-0 winners against Sunderland, with goals from Roberto Firmino, Adam Lallana and Dejan Lovren.

They swam well all day, and it was a good day for them.

Alcohol has a mild euphoric effect on the brain. This reduces your inhibitions, which can make your mind flow a bit more easily, although not necessarily more efficiently. Its important to note that you are not actually thinking better, you just think that you are thinking better, if that makes any sense. This is why programmers, writers, musicians, and other people who need to be creative to work often take up drinking. Sometimes its joked that alcohol is liquid courage, because its easier to express yourself when you feel better. This is also why drunk people seem to think that they can suddenly, magically, sing, dance, or do other silly things. Its worth noting that this is actually very dangerous. Feeling like you have to drink, for any reason, is a major indicator of (at least potential) alcoholism. Your should always monitor your habits, in order to monitor your health. Alcohol can be a boon, but it can also be very dangerous, as can the consequences of failing to drink responsibly.','i feel that I can hear things better..

You could if you wanted to; you just have to practise. I wouldn't recommend doing this though as it could cause permanent vision issues. Normally the convergence of your eyes is controlled essentially automatically by your brain. People have learned to view stereoscopic photos and see the 3D effect without using the special viewers normally required. This means they've learned to take manual control of at least the convergence of their eyes. I suspect, with more effort, you could learn to move them up and down independently too. Of course the stereoscopic example is special in that the eyes can still lock-on to matching images even though they're not converged correctly. Some kind of automatic alignment is still going on. Trying to have each eye turn to view a different object would be much harder. It's not unlike the situation with your breathing; normally it's automatic but you can take manual control if you want. With eyes though this is definitely more difficult.

A 101-year old bottle washed up on a beach with a letter inside. It's for you..... I open the Green Heineken bottle and take out a small, red styrofoam cutout of the letter'F.' I angrily toss the bottle to the ground, instantly shattering it while yelling a four letter word that starts with'F' and rhymes with truck. A brilliant flash of light and a crackling sound fill the air as a random portal appears out of nowhere on the beach and starts sucking anything not anchored to the ground in. I grab onto the nearest tree for dear life just as the smoldering wreckage of my single engine Cessna plane starts sliding across the beach straight into the portal. Rocks, trash and copious amounts of sand are being sucked up by the portal as the island I've been stuck on for 3 long miserable hours after crashing my plane slowly succumbs to the random portal. It didn't take long before the tree I was holding onto became uprooted by the tremendous gravitational pull of the portal, sucking in both the tree and me. I instantly black out. I wake up facedown in wet sand. As I sit up and look around, I realize I'm on a somewhat crowded beach, but everyone is gathered far away from me. Suddenly a bunch of men in white hazmat suits and face shields quickly run up and grab me, forcing me onto a stretcher where they strap me down in three places. I yelp which prompts one of the men to explain that he is with the CDC and that I was in North Carolina. I told him that I couldn't remember what happened and he assures me that everything is going to be ok as they load me into a white van that said CDC on it and drive away.

The world around us is changing at a rapid pace. Technologies that were science fiction just a few short years ago are now commonplace. Students today are digital natives, growing up with technology seamlessly integrated into their daily lives. However, the traditional classroom environment has not always kept step with these changes. Lectures and textbooks remain the primary modes of instruction for many. 

While these time-tested methods certainly have educational value, they fail to capture students' imaginations or spark their innate sense of curiosity about the wider world beyond the four walls of the classroom. A virtual field trip seeks to remedy this by bringing the excitement of real-world exploration directly to students. No longer constrained by logistics or transportation, an entire class can "visit" even the most remote locations with just a few clicks. From the ruins of ancient Rome to the depths of the ocean floor, virtual field trips open a window to places students may never have dreamed of seeing in person.

More than just a novel experience, virtual field trips provide engaging and memorable learning opportunities. Seeing historical sites, natural landscapes, scientific phenomena and more come alive through video and imagery helps cement academic concepts in a student's mind. Things that may have previously seemed abstract in textbooks take on new meaning when encountered in a virtual environment that approximates real experience. Students can examine artifacts up close, participate in guided tours with experts, and gain global cultural perspectives usually unavailable in a typical classroom setting. The interactive elements of many virtual field trip platforms encourage active participation and foster a lifelong enthusiasm for learning.

Perhaps most significantly, virtual field trips promote equity and inclusion in education. They remove barriers of cost, distance, and physical ability that may have previously prevented some students from participating in valuable enrichment activities. Those in rural areas or without means for extensive travel are no longer disadvantaged. Students with disabilities that limit mobility can fully engage with their peers. Every student, regardless of background or circumstance, receives equal access to remarkable educational opportunities typically reserved for a privileged few. In an era when budget cuts threaten arts and elective programs, virtual field trips represent an affordable way to supplement core curriculum with stimulating real-world connections.

Some argue that nothing can truly replace being present in person at important historical sites and natural wonders. And to an extent this is true - there is no substitute for making real observations and forming memories through direct experience. However, virtual field trips can come remarkably close to bridging that gap, especially for students who may never otherwise travel beyond their own communities. When thoughtfully integrated into classroom lessons, they stoke curiosity and bring learning to life. Most importantly, they cultivate a thirst for discovery and open young minds to the incredible diversity of people and places that make up our world. In so doing, virtual field trips play a vital role in enhancing education for the digital native students of today and tomorrow.

Demand response is designed to motivate electricity customers to modify their loads at critical time periods. The accurate estimation of impact of demand response signals to customers' consumption is central to any successful program. In practice, learning these response is nontrivial because operators can only send a limited number of signals. In addition, customer behavior also depends on a large number of exogenous covariates. These two features lead to a high dimensional inference problem with limited number of observations. In this paper, we formulate this problem by using a multivariate linear model and adopt an experimental design approach to estimate the impact of demand response signals. We show that randomized assignment, which is widely used to estimate the average treatment effect, is not efficient in reducing the variance of the estimator when a large number of covariates is present. In contrast, we present a tractable algorithm that strategically assigns demand response signals to customers. This algorithm achieves the optimal reduction in estimation variance, independent of the number of covariates. The results are validated from simulations on synthetic data as well as simulated building data.

The President sat back in his chair whilst dabbing at his brow with a pristine white handkerchief. Jessie noticed the little blue letter P on the handkerchief as he watched, the live feed playing beside him on the laptop. "Well president?" Jessie prompted, eager to hear what the President thought of the new breed of soldier. "Son" He responded "I'm not sure how they are super soldiers, they died like everyone else!" Jessie's eyes flicked to the screen, the feed was lingering on a pile of shredded troops. "Mr President, we went up against 300 enemy soldiers. The enemy were well equipped and well armed Russian forces. We achieved every objective, took every bit of ground and all with minimal losses" Jessie beamed. The handkerchief dabbed again as he leaned forward and controlled the drone's camera. Everywhere he looked displayed destruction, death and multiple bodies of his own people. He frowned as the camera settled on the victories few. "What are the death tolls?" The President quietly enquired. "The enemy forces were obliterated to the man" Jessie replied with a sly grin. "And ours?" The President asked. "Acceptable" Jessie responded curtly. "How many? The President ordered his tone cold. "85 of our forces, leaving us with 39 capable men" Jessie reported, quickly continuing over the Presidents shock that spread across his face "Sir, these men were trained, had the best weapons capable and cost us hardly anything!" Jessie leaned over and flick the screen to display the costings, pointing the chart and comparison. The chart displayed an image along the side of a happy fresh trooper with a 42 cheaper logo displayed on his chest. "See, by cutting costs on food, providing modified starches as rations with a huge array of flavour options we were able to save 24 on food costs." Jessie reported, the words slinking out like a well trained salesman. The President raised a hand to interrupt but Jessie continued. "The barracks and size decrease came back as not only cost effective, but helped with morale as the psyche of all troopers reflected well in forming unit bonds." Jessie reported as the screen changed to display a collection of troopers hugging in a cramped barracks. "Plus, the equipment, weapons, and training was maintained at the standard rates optimising profits for all." "Stop!" The President ordered, the pristine white handkerchief was crushed in a clenched fist. Jessie paused, glanced at the Handkerchief and stiffened. "Son, this is a disaster, I do not want my men suffering and dying." He spoke slowly, his eyes level with Jessie across the table. Jessie nodded once shamefully. "Leave" The President growled, gesturing dismissal and turning in his chair. He had some serious thinking to do and heads would roll. Jessie stood, scooping up the laptop and shuffled to the door. He looked back and offered one last gambit. "These troopers cost us over half of what the Russians committed in that battle sir. These are your new super soldiers."

The Rhine (Romansh: Rein, German: Rhein, French: le Rhin, Dutch: Rijn) is a European river that begins in the Swiss canton of Graubunden in the southeastern Swiss Alps, forms part of the Swiss-Liechtenstein, Swiss-Austrian, Swiss-German and then the Franco-German border, then flows through the Rhineland and eventually empties into the North Sea in the Netherlands. The largest city on the Rhine is Cologne, Germany, with a population of over 1 million people. Other major cities on the river include Basel, Switzerland; Strasbourg, France; Dusseldorf and Duisburg, Germany.

The gasoline supplies only the carbon (C), the oxygen (O2) comes from the atmosphere. Carbon weighs 12 grams per mole, oxygen weighs 16 grams per mole, so for every kilogram of carbon you need 2.67 kilograms of oxygen. The carbon content of gasoline depends on which molecules are in it; if we assume pure octane (C8H18), then 6 pounds of gasoline contains 5 pounds of carbon, which should produce 13 pounds of CO2 which requires 13 pounds of oxygen and produces 18 pounds of CO2 (also, the 1 pound of hydrogen will, after combustion, produce H2O (water) which should weigh 8.5 pounds, if I've done the math correctly). Edit: math correction. Full points to utyr02 for finding the mistake.,because the gasoline is only providing the carbon for the reaction, the O2 is taken out of the air and contributes the bulk of the weight. 2 oxygen for 1 carbon and oxygen weighs more than carbon.','If I have two pounds of eggs then how can I make 6 pounds of pancakes?','In a combustion equations, hydrocarbons (gasoline) react with oxygen from the atmosphere to produce CO2, H2O, and heat. Two oxygens have a molecular weight of 32 while a single carbon has a weight of 12.','The carbon in carbon dioxide comes from what your are burning, the oxygen from the air. A carbon atom weighs about 12 atomic units, an oxygen atom 16. That means about 73 of the mass of the carbon dioxide molecule comes from the air.','The basic form of burning a hydrocarbon in oxygen looks like this: hydrocarbon O2 - energy CO2 H2O stuff The hydrocarbon, like its name implies, is a molecule with a bunch of hydrogen and carbon. For example, burning Octane looks like this: 2 C8H18 25 O2 - 16 CO2 18 H2O Notice that your hydrocarbon here is the C8H18, and the O2 is coming from the environment. So, the CO2 ends up with the mass of all the carbon from the fuel, plus 64 of the mass of the O2 from the environment. All the mass of the H ends up in the H2O, but remember that H is Hydrogen which is the lightest element (in this reaction, by an order of magnitude).','Also consider - How does a whole cake get made from just two eggs? Because there are other ingredients.

"The enemy. Who else?" "And who are we?" "We're the good guys." "Are you sure we're the good guys?" "Of course. We're America. We owe it to ourselves to put our interests first." "You sound like a spoiled child," said the woman. "What do you mean by that?" "Just what I said. You sound like one of those kids in a candy store who grabs all he can as fast as he can and then cries when his father takes him out of the store because his father won't buy him everything he's got his hands on. Your attitude is 'I want this, I want that, I want everything! It's mine! All mine! No one else's! "That's not true!" said the man. "We share!" "Share?" said the woman. "What do you share?" "We share our wealth." "Really?" said the woman. "With whom?" "With our allies." "Allies?" said the woman. "What allies?" "Our friends. The countries that agree with us." "Agree with us about what?" "About everything." "Such as?" "Such as democracy. Freedom. Liberty. Self determination." "Do our allies always agree with us?" "No," said the man. "But that doesn't matter. What matters is that they're our allies." "So," said the woman, "if our allies don't always agree with us, does that make them our enemies?" "No," said the man. "It just means we don't always see eye to eye." "I see," said the woman. "And what about the countries that don't agree with us? Are they our enemies?" "Yes," said the man. "Why?" "Because they're not our friends." "I see," said the woman. "So, in your opinion, the only good country is a country that agrees with us?" "Yes," said the man. "And the only bad country is a country that doesn't agree with us?" "Yes," said the man. "That's a very black and white way of looking at the world," said the woman. "It's the way the world is," said the man.

Dear principal,

I think it would be a great idea for the students at our school to be required to do some community service. It would be a chance for the students to help out in the community, and it would also help the community as well. It is also a way in which students can spend their time wisely.

First of all, the students would be doing a nice thing by helping out in the community. They can help keep the community clean, visit the elderly, or even help out people in their jobs. By this, the people in the community can get some help and the students can learn about people in their community, and their jobs. The students can also get some experience in their field of what they want to be when they grow up. Also, community service is needed to get into college, and the community service can also help a student get into college.

Secondly, it would be a good way for students to spend their time, and students can also learn to manage their time. Instead of staying at home, they can do something which can help other people, and they would also be getting something in return. Students can also learn how to manage their time with their daily schedules, and be able to complete tasks faster, and with good quality.

In my opinion, I think requiring the students at our school to perform community service is a really nice idea. It is a way for them to do something for the community, and it is really good for the students too.

Sincerely, a student

While public transportation has the potential to reduce emissions and congestion, it cannot do so without significant investment. Self-driving and eco-friendly cars can offer a more immediate solution by reducing emissions from individual vehicles, while at the same time easing traffic congestion. Furthermore, many people prefer the convenience of having their own car, and self-driving cars could provide this without the need for additional infrastructure such as rail lines or bus lanes. Therefore, investing in self-driving and eco-friendly cars is not only a more cost-effective option, but it could also have a more immediate impact on emissions and traffic issues.

Car-free cities

Car-free cities are becoming increasingly popular, with more and more cities around the world implementing measures to reduce the number of cars on their roads. While some argue that cars are necessary for modern life, car-free cities offer a range of benefits, including improved air quality, safety, and quality of life for residents. In this essay, we will examine the advantages and disadvantages of car-free cities and explore some examples of cities that have successfully implemented car-free policies.

One of the main benefits of car-free cities is improved air quality. Cars are a major source of pollution, and the number of cars on the road has a direct impact on air quality. By reducing the number of cars, cities can significantly lower pollution levels, which can have a positive impact on the health of residents. This is particularly important in urban areas where air pollution is already a significant public health concern.

Another benefit of car-free cities is improved road safety. Cars are responsible for a significant number of accidents and deaths, particularly in urban areas. By reducing the number of cars on the road, cities can lower the number of accidents, making roads safer for all users, including pedestrians, cyclists, and motorists.

Car-free cities can also improve the quality of life for residents. By reducing the amount of traffic on the road, residents can enjoy a more peaceful and enjoyable urban environment. They can also spend less time sitting in traffic and more time engaging in other activities they enjoy, such as exercising, socializing, or spending time outdoors.

However, there are also some disadvantages to car-free cities. For some people, particularly those with mobility issues, cars are a necessary means of transportation. Without cars, these individuals may find it difficult to access essential services or social activities.

Additionally, car-free cities can be expensive to implement, as they require substantial investments in infrastructure, such as bike paths and pedestrian walkways. This can be challenging for some cities, particularly those with limited financial resources.

So feel free to experiment with the following recipes, start making some now, and share any tips and tricks you learn along the way.

As an adult student, Sarah understood the importance of continuing her education. She was determined to finish her Bachelor's degree, but time constraints were always getting in her way. She worked full-time and had a family to take care of, so finding time to attend classes was nearly impossible. Sarah wasn't the only one facing this challenge; she knew many other adult students who were struggling with the same issue.

Sarah had heard about online e-learning courses as a potential solution to this problem. The idea of being able to study whenever and wherever she wanted was appealing. She decided to try one of these courses, hoping it would help her manage her time better and allow her to continue her education.

At first, Sarah was excited about the flexibility of online learning. She could log in to her course whenever she had a free moment, whether it was early in the morning or late at night. She could also study from the comfort of her own home, which was a huge relief for her.

However, Sarah soon realized that online courses were not without their challenges. For starters, she found it difficult to stay motivated when she was not in a classroom environment. It was easy to get distracted by other tasks or activities at home, and before she knew it, hours had passed without any progress on her coursework.

Another issue Sarah faced was the lack of interaction with her fellow students and instructors. In a traditional classroom setting, she could engage in discussions, ask questions, and receive immediate feedback. In her online course, she felt isolated and disconnected from the learning community.

Despite these challenges, Sarah was determined to make her online course work for her. She started setting aside specific times during the day to study, just as she would if she were attending a traditional class. She also tried to find ways to stay motivated, such as joining a study group or participating in online discussions.

Over time, Sarah began to see improvements in her online coursework. She felt more focused and motivated, and she enjoyed the flexibility that online learning offered. While she still felt some disconnection from her fellow students and instructors, she found ways to overcome this challenge by reaching out and engaging in discussions whenever possible.

In the end, Sarah realized that online courses were not a magic solution to her time constraints. However, they were a valuable resource that could help her continue her education while juggling work and family responsibilities. She was grateful for the opportunity to learn in a way that worked for her, and she was inspired to continue pursuing her academic goals.

**More people decided to have children in their later age than in the past. Why? Do advantages of this outweigh disadvantages?**  
  
It is the fact that nowadays numerous adults have their first children in their thirties or more which is somewhat later than the previous generation. This trend, which is caused by several reasons, certainly introduces both merit and demerit, but it seems to me that the advantages do outweigh the disadvantages.  
  
There are some factors which in turn make people have babies at later age consisting of career orientation and cost expenses. About career path, many people give much more priority for their job in lieu of settling down and having babies because the belief that when they were young they could promote to upper position easily. When having a baby, they have to spend more time on their offspring which means it could hinder their determination and concentration on works, especially for women. Turning to other reasons relating financial aspect, the money for bringing up a child is so large. When a baby was born, there are myriad fees have to be paid such as hospital, health care, education, food and so on, which could be considered as a burden for some families.  
  
Some disadvantages may come from this idea including the negative influence on both the baby and pregnant, I, however, still believe that the benefits are worthwhile to do so. It is obvious that the more women aging, the more their health gets weaker and that might harmfully impact their pregnant period. Nevertheless, the decision having babies later gives parents more time to prepare deliberately not only financial support but also the education for their child. Indeed, children with older parents receive better education; the reason is that their parents have more experience in teaching them to be a good citizens. This trend, therefore, seems to be a good trend for society.  
  
In conclusion, both the favor of career and the financial factor are the main reasons to delay having babies in many families. Although this trend has some demerits, I still believe the huge benefits including better preparation are more dominant.

I am writing to you today to argue in favor of keeping the Electoral College or changing to election by popular vote for the president of the United States. I know that this is an important issue, and I want to make sure that my opinion is heard. I would like to start by addressing the counterclaims that I have heard.

Some people argue that the Electoral College is outdated and that we should change to election by popular vote. I disagree. I think that the Electoral College is an important part of our democracy. It ensures that all states have a voice in the election process.

Others argue that the Electoral College is unfair because it gives more weight to smaller states. I disagree. I think that the Electoral College is fair because it gives all states an equal voice.

I would like to conclude by saying that I think the Electoral College is an important part of our democracy and that I think it should stay the way it is. I hope that you will take my opinion into consideration when making your decision.

Thank you,

A diligent but not particularly innovative student

Tryouts for my school's soccer team are only twenty days away and my practice schedule has been vigorous to say the least. Every day I run and practice dribbling, shooting, juggling, and passing drills to help better my game. However, if someone had asked me about playing and training for soccer ten months ago I would have been in utter disbelief. That's because ten months ago my body was nearly twice as big, I was obese by nearly forty pounds, and my health was declining rapidly. My journey began in a doctor's waiting room. The usual waiting had already come to pass and at last the doctor entered the room. Little did I know his news would change my entire life. He strictly informed me that my liver was not functioning properly due to my weight and that I weighed far too much for my height and age. If I ever wanted to live a long and healthy life, something would have to change. To say that his news was daunting is an understatement. I had already tried numerous times to lose the weight, but it simply never worked. My body just didn't seem programmed to keep off the pounds. However, I knew that if something didn't change I would never be able to experience the things in life I love like playing soccer or hiking for miles in the misty mountains of China or even live to see the fulfillment of my life, so I began to run. Every day after school I would come home and gear up for my daily run around the neighborhood. At first my distances were small. I would barely make five-hundred feet at a slow jog, but before I knew it I was running nearly five kilometers every day. With the running came a drastic change in my body. The weight seemed to disappear into thin air. I felt like every stride I took in my running shoes was a step that burned the barriers in life that my excess weight had created. Ten months later and the changes are remarkable. I've lost nearly ninety pounds since I began running in February and many new opportunities have become available. Now that I could run much more, I was able to begin playing soccer with some people I knew from my school and I learned that I love the game. My weight loss has enabled me to make numerous new friends that I would never have been able to meet outside a soccer field. The literal loss of half of my mass has made me faster, stronger, and a happier person overall, and now I can't wait for those soccer tryouts at the end of January to finally bring all of my hard work to a culmination.

Young Goodman Brown by Nathaniel Hawthrone Essay

Table of Contents
 1. Quotations
 2. Qualities
 3. Questions
 4. Work Cited

Quotations

The most compelling quote from “Young Goodman Brown” is probably the following: “Depending upon one another’s hearts, ye had still hoped that virtue was not all a dream. Now, are ye undeceived? Evil is the nature of mankind (Hawthorne, p. 408).” The Devil is trying to persuade the main character that the world as he sees it through the moral lens is an illusion. Evil, however, is the reality that every person will have to face. Another quotation that captures the reader’s attention is: “With Heaven above and Faith below, I will yet stand firm against the Devil! (Hawthorne, p. 409)” Goodman Brown rejects the worldview perpetuated by the Devil and calls for the Higher Power (Heaven) to help him. Interestingly enough, Faith can be interpreted ambiguously – literally and as the name of his wife. In the second case, Brown might mean that the bond that he has with his wife is what makes him persistent in opposing evil.

Qualities

The story by Hawthorne includes six essential elements of fiction: character, plot, point of view, setting, style, and themes. The main character is young Goodman Brown, a puritan who moved to the New World with his wife. The plot is built around his journey into a mysterious forest – the main setting in this literary piece. While the story is written in the third person, the reader has access to Brown’s point of view and can empathize with his feelings. The style is intentionally gothic and grotesque insofar as the themes discussed – temptation, loss of faith, and madness.

Questions

“Young Goodman Brown” raises many questions that remain unanswered and, therefore, are open to interpretation. The reader cannot tell precisely whether what Brown encountered in the forest was real, or he merely dreamed it. There is some evidence that the vision that Goodman Brown had was nothing but a dream. Throughout his journey, his perception of the surroundings is indistinct and lacks detail. When Brown meets an old traveler, he realizes certain similarities between them, which may mean that the protagonist met his subconscious self in his dream. Another question that compels the reader to develop a deeper understanding of the story is whether the Devil himself made Brown hallucinate the entire encounter. The testing of faith is a common theme in Protestantism, which makes this explanation feasible.

Work Cited

Hawthorne, Nathaniel. “Young Goodman Brown.” The Story and Its Writer: An Introduction to Short Fiction. Compact ninth ed. Ed. Ann Charters. Boston: Bedford/St. Martin’s, 2015. 405-414. Print.

Every day was a struggle for Sarah. Some days, she woke up feeling sick and weak. She couldn't even get out of bed without feeling dizzy and nauseous. Other days, she woke up feeling hopeful that her suffering would finally come to an end. It had been two years since Sarah was diagnosed with a rare and aggressive type of cancer. She underwent intense chemotherapy and radiation treatments, but the cancer persisted. Doctors told her that her chances of survival were slim. Sarah tried to stay positive and live her life to the fullest, but it was difficult when she spent most of her days in bed, too weak to move. She missed going out with her friends, going on vacations, and simply feeling healthy. On the days when she felt like she was dying, Sarah couldn't help but feel defeated and hopeless. She wished the pain and suffering would end, and that she could finally find peace. But then there were the other days. The days when Sarah felt determined to keep fighting. She would listen to motivational speeches and read inspiring books. She would think of all the things she still wanted to accomplish in life and how much she wanted to see her loved ones again. It was a constant battle between hope and despair. Some days, Sarah didn't know how she could keep going. Other days, she was determined to prove the doctors wrong and beat her illness. Despite her ups and downs, Sarah never gave up. She relied on her faith and the support of her loved ones to keep her going. And though she never knew what each day would bring, she faced it with courage and resilience.

The Strangest Dream I Ever Had

It was a typical Wednesday morning when I woke up from the most bizarre dream I have ever had. In my dream, I found myself floating in mid-air above a fluffy pink cloud, surrounded by talking cats wearing sunglasses. Yes, you read that right - talking cats! They were all dressed in their best 70s outfits, complete with bell-bottom jeans and platform shoes. One of them, a sleek black feline named Felix, offered me a plate of spaghetti covered in melted ice cream. Now, don't ask me why, but for some reason, this was the strangest thing I had ever seen in my life. So naturally, being the curious person that I am, I decided to dig deeper into the meaning behind this absurd vision. On closer inspection, I noticed every single cat in sight had a miniature piano strapped around their neck, playing melodies that seemed to match the rhythm of their heartbeats. Suddenly, one of the felines pointed at me with his collar-mounted laser pointer and shouted "Cowabonga!" Then, before I could even blink twice, they all started singing together in perfect harmony while performing acrobatic stunts. Unbelievable! That was indeed the craziest dream I ever had. What did it mean? Was it simply a product of a wild imagination running wild after eating too many tacos for lunch? Or perhaps there was more to uncover beneath its superficial surface? As if sensing my confusion, all of those talking kitties suddenly vanished into thin air without warning leaving nothing more than a faint trail of glitter behind them. And so goes another enigmatic journey through subconscious realms where anything seems plausible until awakened again by the morning light peeping through windowsill curtains."

“A Theory of Temporary Organization” by Lundin and Söderholm Research Paper

Since the industrial era, the idea of an organization as an eternal entity has dominated business studies. However, modern economic and social tendencies gave rise to an increased number of temporary projects and organizations and generated a need for a comprehensive theoretical basis. Aiming at providing a framework for understanding the temporary organizations’ specific, Lundin and Söderholm elaborated on the idea of an action-based theory, four basic concepts for the organization demarcation as well as sequencing concepts.

The action was singled out as the predominant factor in apprehending the essence of temporary organizations as opposed to the notion of decision-making as the primary determinant. The researchers claimed that decisions do not always bring about actions; on the contrary, decisions are consequential to actions. It was established that the prime source of motivation in business is the necessity to act. Thus, the new theory should be stressing the nature of the action and its aspects.

Further, the researchers introduce four concepts for defining action areas and demarcating a temporary organization. According to Lunden and Sömerholm, a temporary organization can be described regarding time, task, team, and transition. In contrast, a permanent organization is rather explained by its goals (instead of tasks), survival (instead of time), working organization (instead of the team), and sustainable development (instead of transition). The said concepts, however, only demarcate actions but do not give a detailed account as to what they entail.

Lunden and Sömerholm employ four sequencing concepts for action description; each represents a phase in running a temporary project or organization. At the entrepreneurial stage, it is crucial to provide the driving force for business creation. Further on, time brackets, tasks, and termination criteria are to be specified, which is followed by the task execution and the timely dissolution of a temporary organization. The authors argue that the possibility of interruption at any stage does not undermine the validity of the concepts.

Lunden and Sömerholm strove to establish the phenomenon of temporary organizations in its entirety and give the impetus to further analysis. In the future, one may investigate successful temporary organizations and the actions they took in order to pass all the sequencing stages. On the contrary, it may be useful to study stagnated organizations, for the interest as to why the plans failed is equally justifiable.

Reference List

Lundin, RA & Söderholm, A 1995, ‘A theory of the temporary organization’, Scandinavian Journal of Management , vol. 11, no. 4, pp. 437-455.

Write about the following topic.Many people use written language in a less formal and more relaxed way. Why? Does this development have advantages and disadvantages?Give reasons for your answer and include any relevant examples from your own knowledge or experience.Nowadays, written language is used in comparatively more informal and relaxed way. I assume that it happens because of the need of making communication easier and faster. Without features of formal written language it is simplier to share your idea in a shorter period of time. This option is essential in a modern temp of life. This essay will cover both advantages and disadvantages of this development.
The less formal and tense written language provides some pros. First of all, without formalization the process of communication requires less amount of time. Then letters consists of less number of symbols and can help to solve the discussed problem much faster. Moreover, this way of communication does not support formal borders between members of a dialogue. Then it is easier to come closer with the interlocutor and feel no pressure during the using of written language.
On the other hand, development of making written language more informal and relaxed has some cons. Firstly, communication goes less respectful. Then interlocutors have almost no opportunity to pay a respect to each other. Formalized written language is significant in issue of social borders that can hihlight a paid respect. Secondly, sometimes the main gist of the letter goes unclear, because informal language is more relaxed. In these conditions, the quidity of the letter can be hidden with less formal features. If participants of the communication are not close, they will not understand each other correctly.
In conclusion I would like to say that the process of using written language in a more informal way has both advantages and disadvantages. It can be revealed in different situations. That is why everyone should have their own opinion based on the information discussed in this essay.

Alexander Wotherspoon, 83, appeared at Paisley Sheriff Court charged with causing the death of Eilish Herron by driving without due care and attention. The 17-year-old was struck by Mr Wotherspoon's car at an Asda petrol station in Linwood in September 2014. The charge says he had failed to keep control of the car while reversing. Mr Wotherspoon, from Houston in Renfrewshire, uses a zimmer frame to help him walk. He denied starting the engine of his car and reversing while the driver's door was still open, failing to keep control of the car and, while it was reversing, causing it to hit the Renault Clio Eilish was filling up with petrol. The charge states that his actions knocked her to the ground, moved her car out of the way and caused his car to reverse over her, dragging her underneath the car, "causing her to be so severely injured that she died." The incident happened at the Asda petrol station at the Phoenix Retail Park in Linwood on 10 September 2014. Sheriff Susan Sinclair adjourned the case for a trial to take place in August and continued Wotherspoon's bail. Speaking previously, Eilish's mother Shanneal, 47, said: "Eilish was a really good girl, a normal teenager who loved her life, loved her family and loved her sport. "She was my best friend, we had such a good laugh. "I can't put into words how much she's missed in our family. We are all very close." Eilish was a keen netball player and played for Paisley Juniors as well as volunteering as a junior coach. After her death, Netball Scotland created the The Eilish Herron Young Coach of the Year Award, which will continue as a yearly recognition award for young coaches.

The Full Self-Driving beta v9 comes with the following improvements: Stability, and also reduced steering torque on vehicles without rear view mirrors Road Identification, where the system now works with additional roadways, including bike paths, sidewalks, etc. Snapshots taken by the vehicle are more accurately used to identify the surrounding objects The system is now able to identify other vehicles and cyclists on the road, as well as road signs and stop signs. In the realm of psychology, virtual reality (VR) has emerged as a promising tool for treating various mental health conditions. This cutting-edge technology has the potential to revolutionize the way mental health professionals approach psychological disorders, as it offers a safe, controlled, and immersive environment for patients to confront their fears and phobias, practice coping strategies, and ultimately, foster healing. VR-based therapy has shown to be particularly effective in treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), phobias, anxiety disorders, and even some forms of addiction. This essay delves into the role of virtual reality in treating psychological disorders, exploring its benefits, limitations, and future implications.


One of the most significant advantages of VR in treating psychological disorders is its ability to recreate real-life situations in a controlled setting. Patients can be gradually exposed to their fears or traumatic memories in a safe, therapeutic environment, allowing them to build coping skills and resilience. For example, VR exposure therapy has been found to be an effective treatment for specific phobias, such as fear of heights (acrophobia), spiders (arachnophobia), and flying (aviophobia). By exposing patients to these fear-inducing stimuli in a controlled VR environment, they can learn to manage their anxiety and fear responses in a safe space, without the real-world consequences of their phobias. This controlled exposure can help patients habituate to their fears, resulting in reduced anxiety and improved daily functioning.


Similarly, VR has shown promise in treating PTSD. Individuals with PTSD often experience intrusive memories

Whether or not education is a life-long process is a complicated question. On one hand, there are many things that can be learned outside of formal education institutions. On the other hand, formal education does provide structure and support that can make learning more effective. Ultimately, whether or not education is a life-long process depends on the individual.

There are many things that can be learned outside of formal education institutions. For example, people can learn how to cook, garden, or fix a car without going to school. In addition, people can learn about different cultures and religions by travelling and interacting with people from different backgrounds. Furthermore, many jobs do not require formal education, and people can learn the necessary skills through on-the-job training.

However, formal education does provide structure and support that can make learning more effective. For example, schools provide a safe and supportive environment in which children can learn. In addition, schools offer resources such as books, computers, and experienced teachers. Furthermore, schools can offer specialized programs that are not available outside of formal education institutions.

Ultimately, whether or not education is a life-long process depends on the individual. Some people are self-motivated and can learn effectively on their own, while others benefit from the structure and support that formal education provides. There is no right or wrong answer, and each person must decide what works best for them.

Ways to Keep Your Business Going in Hard Times Case Study

Any business venture can run into financial difficulties and be unable to maintain commitments and meet financial obligations. Economic changes, overreliance on credit, and unexpected expenses can contribute to the owner being unable to afford the operating costs, pay bills, and pay the employees. When coming upon challenging times, business owners should understand whether internal or external factors caused the financial difficulties and assess whether cutbacks can be made.

If I were an employer facing difficult financial times, I would attempt to resolve the situation without having to lay off employees. I would ensure that at least 10% of free cash flow in each quarter is deposited into a savings account that can be accessed to ensure the company can pay for operating costs, such as payroll, property rent, and taxes (Curtis, 2020). I would consider cutting capital expenditures unless investment in new properties or equipment is instrumental in preventing the business from shutting down or laying off employees. Furthermore, certain business assets can be liquidated; however, it is important to assess all assets and dispose of those that do not add value to the company (Curtis, 2020). Alternatively, bank and peer-to-peer loans can be considered (Kagan, 2020). Overall, it is critical to ensure that the company always has access to cash and can pay for its day-to-day expenses.

Nevertheless, it should be acknowledged that in some cases laying off employees cannot be avoided. A review of staff should be performed to determine whether workers are productive and secure the further employment of the most efficient employees (Curtis, 2020). Inefficient workers that do not contribute to the business’s development should be laid off. However, the human resources department of the company should prevent ethical concerns from arising. Thus, employees should be dismissed based only on their performance and the set termination criteria. The dismissed personnel should be awarded with severance packages and given a letter of recommendation to ease future employment. In summary, any business struggling to maintain commitments and meet financial obligations should consider several options that will allow it to stay afloat, including accessing savings, taking out loans, liquifying assets, and laying off inefficient employees.

References

Curtis, G. (2020). 5 ways to keep your business going in hard times . Investopedia. Web.

Kagan, J. (2020). Peer-to-peer lending: The lowdown . Investopedia. Web.

The Party of Reconstruction in Sicily, which claimed 40,000 members in 1944, campaigned for Sicily to be admitted as a U.S. state. This party was one of several Sicilian separatist movements active after the downfall of Italian Fascism. Sicilians felt neglected or underrepresented by the Italian government after the annexation of 1861 that ended the rule of the Kingdom of the Two Sicilies based in Naples. The large population of Sicilians in America and the American-led Allied invasion of Sicily in July-August 1943 may have contributed to the sentiment.

Protests have been taking place in over 150 locations across the United States to demand President Donald Trump release his tax returns. The 'Tax March' is a nationwide demonstration organised by Tax March, an organisation that seeks to "demand transparency from the president and for him to disclose his taxes." They are calling on the public to join them in protesting for Trump to make his tax information public. The protests come after a long period of speculation about Trump's tax history and whether he has avoided paying federal income taxes in past years. It follows his refusal to release any of his financial records during the campaign, which would have shed some light on his past financial dealings. The demonstrations have been a huge success, with people gathering in cities such as New York, Los Angeles and Washington DC, as well as smaller towns and cities across the country. Many protesters held up signs reading "show us your taxes" or "release your taxes," while others chanted slogans such as "What do we want? Taxes! When do we want them? Now!" The protests were largely peaceful, though there were reports of some scuffles between protesters and police in some cities. The White House has yet to respond to the protests, but a statement from the president's spokesman said: "President Trump is proud of the fact that he pays his taxes and has fought hard to reduce the tax burden of all Americans." The protests show no sign of slowing down, and many believe they will continue until the president releases his tax returns. It remains to be seen what effect these protests will have, but it seems clear that the American public are determined to hold their president to account.

The New Media Role in Modern Society Essay

Technological advance has resulted in business transitioning online, which, in turn, requires efficient market placements online through media. Naturally, traditional sources people are used to are now outweighed by the numerous benefits of new media. To be more exact, legacy media targets a broad audience, which is, obviously, ineffective and leads to companies wasting their money on a few integrations. This type of promotion focuses on old news presentations, such as billboards, television commercials, or printed materials (Vara-Miguel, 2020). Therefore, the audience that sees the advertisements is not narrowed correctly, meaning that most viewers do not find the commercials exciting and do not buy the presented products.

In contrast, new media is adjusted to the modern view of society that is constantly engaged in interaction with various technological devices. In addition, Generation Z is more likely to be motivated to purchase the advertised goods when seeing the advertisements on social media (Vara-Miguel, 2020). That is why new media is mainly positioned on popular social networks, such as YouTube, Instagram, Twitter, and especially Tik Tok (Vara-Miguel, 2020). The influencers partner with many companies, advertising their products or service online to their followers, which is apparently more efficient than the old methods of legacy media. By and large, people are more likely to buy the items that are recommended by their favorite bloggers, models, actors, and other celebrities or accomplished social-media influencers.

The control of social media users makes paid promotions more productive, considering that people’s online activity is being tracked and analyzed to define their interests, preferences, and desires. In other words, new media does not understand the notion of privacy whatsoever since individual information is being implemented to manipulate society to make the leading businesses even richer (Surette, 2022). As a result, new media is a reason for rapidly increasing victimization as internet users are being followed to any websites they visit, videos they watch and comments they leave.

Reference

Surette, R. (2022). Media, crime, and criminal justice (3 edition). Wadsworth Publishing.

Vara-Miguel, A. (2020). Cross-National similarities and differences between legacy and Digital-Born news media audiences. Media and Communication , 8 (2), 16–27. Web.

Malaysian Airlines has announced that Chief Executive Christoph Mueller has resigned after less than a year in office. The German native had been leading the airline's reorganizing efforts since May 2015 in an effort to make the company more competitive. The resignation comes as Malaysian Airlines struggles to return to financial health after two major disasters in 2014. In March of that year, Flight 370 disappeared without a trace, while in July, Flight 17 was shot down over Ukraine, killing all 298 people on board. Mueller had been working to restore confidence in the airline, and recently announced plans to cut 6,000 jobs and reduce the number of aircraft it operates by 30. He had also aimed to increase customer satisfaction by introducing low-cost fares, streamlining services and improving on-time performance. Although the company did not provide an explanation for Mueller's resignation, analysts suggest that he may have been frustrated with the slow progress of the restructuring process. For now, Malaysian Airlines will be headed by a team of executive directors appointed by the Malaysian government, who will continue working to turn around the ailing carrier.

A senior judge is to review the controversial Offensive Behaviour at Football Act (OBFA), as part of a review of Scotland's hate crime laws. The OBFA, which was introduced in 2012, criminalises behaviour that is "likely to incite public disorder" at football matches. It has been criticised by some for being too broad and for targeting football fans specifically. Now, Lord Bracadale, who is leading the review of hate crime legislation, has said that he will consider whether the OBFA "goes too far." Speaking to the BBC, he said: "I think it's important that we look at all the legislation that's in place... to see whether it's fit for purpose, whether it's working as intended, and also to look at whether there's anything else that might be required." He added that the review would be "open-minded" and would consider all the evidence before making any recommendations. The OBFA has been credited with helping to reduce sectarianism and offensive behaviour at football matches, but it remains a controversial law. It will be interesting to see what Lord Bracadale's review concludes.

Good restatement with the slight problem of you still using the phrase "which possessing" in the presentation. The best scored paraphrasing is always the one that avoids any word usage from the original. that is because it shows a high degree of vocabulary, English comprehension, and thought process. You have shown an ability to do this in the restatement section. So just work on further improving that skill by avoiding all original word usage.  
  
You are over explaining in the presentation. You have to work within a 250-300 word frame only. That is because of the 40 minute time limit for the presentation. I understand that you have an extensive English vocabulary and you want to show the examiner your English skills as thoroughly as possible. However, the aim of this test is to have you show that you can explain your understanding, opinion, and dis/agreement with a given topic as quickly and clearly as you can. Do not get me wrong, you did a thorough job of explaining yourself. The problem, is that the examiner needs to be able to quickly read the presentation, hence the word allowance.

In the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile," the author describes how a new technology called the Facial Action Coding System enables computers to identify human emotions. This technology can be used to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom.

Some people argue that this technology is valuable because it can help teachers to understand how their students are feeling. They say that this can be useful in a number of different situations, such as when a student is struggling with a particular topic or is feeling overwhelmed.

Others argue that this technology is not valuable because it is not always accurate. They say that the computer might misinterpret a student's expression or might not be able to pick up on subtle emotions.

I think that the use of this technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom is valuable. I think that it can help teachers to understand their students and to provide them with the support that they need.

Hits 1 Million Downloads Software development platform GitHub announced that its Axum programming language repository has hit the one million mark in downloads. Axum, which is based on Microsoft's C language, offers a way to create distributed applications with high-level abstractions and low-level control. It is designed to be a powerful tool for developing software on the cloud. In a statement made by GitHub, they said that this achievement was a testament to the hard work of their developers and the support of the open source community. The company also thanked the users who have helped make this milestone possible. Axum was first released in 2018 and quickly gained traction among developers due to its ease of use and its ability to write code quickly. The popularity of the language has only grown since then, as more developers discovered its benefits. The language is especially popular among those who are creating distributed applications or working with large data sets. Its features include asynchronous programming, message-based communication, actor model for concurrent programming, and much more. GitHub hopes that as Axum continues to grow in popularity, it will become a key part of the software development ecosystem. As more developers turn to the language for their projects, the number of users and downloads is expected to rise even further.

The VA Theatre Performance galleries, formerly the Theatre Museum, opened in March 2009. The collections are stored by the VA, and are available for research, exhibitions and other shows. They may be viewed at the Gallery Store below or on this website; the store offers unique gift items from local artists as well. Museum of Fine Arts, Houston - In May 2008, the MFAH became a major collecting institution when it purchased two important works by Mark Rothko. One is an untitled 1940 painting whose oil-on-linen surface was reportedly found to have been painted over. (More about that later.) Also included was his celebrated 1967 painting Nude Descending a Staircase I (more about that painting here). Precollections are not being sold off...yet! Several months ago, there were rumors circulating that the Precollections would be sold off soon because of budget concerns. There actually has been no decision yet made about what will happen with these treasures; the rumor was simply based upon a number of factors including statements made by President Smith regarding difficult decisions and new priorities. Said Mr. Smith at one recent gathering: "We're going to look down our list again - everything we own at the museum - and figure out how to make sure those things stay in their home institutions so they can continue to educate people about who we are [as a nation]." As mentioned earlier, the new director is Dr. Kyung Wha Chung. As she becomes involved intimately with all aspects of the precollectsion process, her perspective is likely to change significantly. We do know that she hired the respected art historian Richard Armstrong to conduct a thorough review of the archives in February 2011. This led to the conclusion that many archival materials need to be digitized and preserved more carefully before they eventually move into storage. Thus far, however, the most publicized news about the Precollections involves the discovery of the untitled 1940 work which had apparently never previously been seen by anyone but the artist himself - and perhaps some staff members working nearby. When discovered recently during restoration work, it was covered in cobwebs and torn by previous visitors. A single wooden frame, measuring just 2 feet x 5 inches, filled with tar paper was also recovered. According to Ms. Chen, some bits of paint flakes remain attached to the canvas - but no discernible outlines reveal its original design. What remains unclear is whether the current owner believes his painting is worth any money, given its condition. If so, heshe might consider having it cleaned up professionally instead of selling it for a few hundred dollars via eBay.

Coca-Cola: “Taste the Feeling” Campaign Case Study

Table of Contents
 1. Highlights
 2. Objectives
 3. Other departments
 4. References

Highlights

The campaign seeks to capitalize on Coca-Cola as an iconic cultural brand which goes back to the roots of its origins as a ‘social’ beverage which brings people together. The campaign aims to create a perspective that Coca-Cola can be present at the heart of any positive experience or life story. However, a substantial focus is put on the unifying aspect. Just as the campaign unifies the brand, it does so with the customers as well. Since the world is so diverse, people may enjoy distinct types of Coke in a variety of situations. Building on the emotional aspect, the campaign tries to include human senses. The drinks are visually rebranded to become brighter and simple, similar to the original Coca-Colas. The campaign features a catchy song by a world-renowned artist as well as the use of high definition sounds in its advertisements such as the fizzing of the bottle being opened, or the liquid being poured. Finally, Coca-Cola uses the driving force behind its product, the taste. This campaign seeks to market that the emotion and drive seen visually in the commercials is experienced through “tasting the feeling.”

Objectives

The campaign was brilliantly developed to have a wide variety of marketing applications to address challenges that Coca-Cola was facing with its carbonated drinks. The simplicity of the campaign and its focus on narratives is extremely appealing, touching many emotions and “feelings” that millennials strive to experiences. Furthermore, customer participation in the campaign made it more inclusive and recognizable through the unified visuals which represented the brand. In the modern consumer economy, where health and fitness are predominant ideas, soda is losing market share. The campaign established an association of Coca-Cola with not just a drive of emotions but also an active lifestyle. The soft drink becomes energizing and is offered in a variety of choices including diet versions.

Other departments

This initiative and marketing campaign was launched to unite all global Coca-Cola drinks under one brand and slogan. It was created after continuing declining soda sales and market share loss to other beverages. It is also an attempt to streamline operations as the company produced a plan to cut almost $3 billion in expenses (Heilpern, 2016). This campaign is important since it takes on a critical business principle of universality. By creating a unified brand, Coca-Cola automatically simplified many of its operations from marketing to production to distribution. It no longer needed to spread its financial and human resources attempting to manage a variety of different campaigns for each beverage.

References

Coca-Cola. (2016,). COCA-COLA anthem [Video file]. Web.

Heilpern, W. (2016). Coca-Cola just launched a massive new ad campaign to change the conversation around sugary drinks.

Moye, J. (2016) ‘One Brand’ strategy, new global campaign unite Coca-Cola trademark . Web.

As an 8th grader, I believe that graduating from high school in three years rather than four has several cons. While some people may argue that this would save time and money, I believe that it would have a negative impact on students' education and future prospects.

Firstly, graduating in three years would mean that students would have to take more classes in a shorter period of time. This would likely lead to a reduction in the quality of education that students receive. With less time to learn and absorb the material, students may not be fully prepared for the challenges that come with college or the workforce. Additionally, with more classes in a shorter period of time, students may not have the opportunity to take elective courses or participate in extracurricular activities that they are interested in.

Secondly, graduating in three years would likely have a negative impact on students' future prospects. Many colleges and employers require a certain number of years of education or work experience before considering applicants. If students were to graduate in three years, they may not have the same level of experience or qualifications as their peers who graduated in four years. This could make it more difficult for them to find jobs or get accepted into college.

Finally, graduating in three years would also mean that students would have to make decisions about their future earlier than they would if they graduated in four years. This could be stressful and overwhelming for some students, as they may not be fully prepared to make such important decisions at such a young age. Additionally, if students were to graduate in three years and then decide to pursue further education or training, they may not have the same level of financial support or resources as they would if they had graduated in four years.

In conclusion, while graduating from high school in three years may seem like a good idea, I believe that it has several cons. It would lead to a reduction in the quality of education that students receive, have a negative impact on their future prospects, and make it more difficult for them to make important decisions about their future. I believe that it is important for students to have the time and resources to fully prepare for their future, and graduating in four years allows for this.

The Great Wall of China stands as a testament to the resilience, determination, and ingenuity of the Chinese people. It is a symbol of the nation's rich history, cultural identity, and military prowess. This monumental structure, stretching over 13,000 miles and spanning across various dynasties, has not only played a pivotal role in the defense of China but also served as an embodiment of the Chinese spirit. The Great Wall's significance can be examined from various perspectives, including its historical context, architectural grandeur, and cultural impact.

The construction of the Great Wall began as early as the 7th century BC, during the reign of the first Chinese emperor, Qin Shi Huang. However, the Wall that stands today was mainly built during the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644). The Ming emperors embarked on a massive project to consolidate and expand the Wall in response to the invasions by nomadic tribes from the north, such as the Mongols and the Jurchens. The Wall served as a defensive barrier, providing a strategic advantage to the Chinese in their battles against these adversaries.

The architectural grandeur of the Great Wall is a marvel of human engineering. The Wall was constructed using a variety of materials, including rammed earth, wood, brick, and stone. It traverses diverse terrain, from the rugged mountains to the arid deserts, showcasing the ingenuity of the Chinese builders in adapting the Wall to the local environment. The Wall also features numerous watchtowers, barracks, and beacon towers, which allowed for effective communication and coordination of the military forces stationed along its length.

The Great Wall's cultural significance extends beyond its military purpose. It is a symbol of Chinese unity, representing the collective effort of the people across different dynasties to protect their homeland. The Wall has also become a symbol of the Chinese spirit, embodying values such as perseverance, sacrifice, and determination. The Wall has been celebrated in literature, poetry, and art, reflecting its deep-rooted place in Chinese culture.

Furthermore, the Great Wall has become a symbol of human accomplishment and an enduring testament to the power of collective effort. The Wall's vast scale and the sheer number of people involved in its construction serve as a reminder of the incredible feats that can be achieved when individuals come together for a common cause.

In conclusion, the Great Wall of China is a monument of immense historical, architectural, and cultural significance. Its role as a defensive barrier against invasions, its architectural grandeur, and its cultural symbolism all contribute to the Wall's enduring importance. As a testament to the Chinese people's resilience, determination, and unity, the Great Wall will continue to captivate and inspire generations to come.

The Ethics and Philosophy of Virtual Reality Experiences

Virtual reality has always been a fascinating topic for both philosophers and ethicists. It is a realm where reality and imagination blend, raising numerous questions about the nature of existence, consciousness, and our perception of the world. In this essay, we will explore the complexities of virtual reality experiences, focusing on their philosophical and ethical implications.

First and foremost, the concept of reality is at the heart of virtual reality experiences. In the virtual world, one can interact with objects and people as if they were real, even though they are merely digital representations. This raises questions about the nature of reality itself. Are virtual objects as real as physical objects? Do they have the same essence or properties as real-world objects? These questions lead us to the age-old philosophical debate: Can we trust our senses to discern the truth about the world around us?

The concept of consciousness is another crucial aspect of virtual reality experiences. When we put on a VR headset, our brains are tricked into believing that we are in a different world, even though our bodies remain in the physical world. This begs the question: What is consciousness, and how does it relate to the brain? Renowned philosopher John Searle argues that consciousness is simply a neural process that arises from the brain's biological functions. However, some philosophers, such as Panpsychism proponents, believe that consciousness is a fundamental and universal aspect of reality, present even in non-biological entities like rocks and planets.

As we delve deeper into the world of virtual reality, we must also consider its profound impact on our understanding of morality and ethics. Virtual reality allows us to engage in activities and situations that we would never encounter in real life, such as committing violent acts or stealing. This raises questions about the nature of morality and the moral implications of our actions in virtual reality. Is it possible to be truly moral in a virtual environment? And if so, how can we ensure that the lessons we learn in virtual reality translate to our real-world experiences?

Furthermore, the realm of virtual reality presents new challenges for the concept of personal identity. In a virtual world, we can create avatars and personas that are vastly different from our real selves. This raises questions about the nature of personal identity and what makes us who we are. Are our virtual selves just as real as our physical selves? Or is there a fundamental difference between them?

In conclusion, virtual reality experiences present an intriguing and complex landscape for philosophers and ethicists alike. As technology continues to advance, we must grapple with the profound questions that virtual reality raises about the nature of reality, consciousness, morality, and personal identity. While the answers to these questions may be elusive, engaging in the dialogue is essential for understanding the true implications of virtual reality experiences.

IELTS WRITING TASK 2 on building styles  
  
**Question:**  
***In many cities the constructions of new houses and office building is not controlled. This leads to people building in whatever style they want without thinking about design.***  
  
## Do the advantages of this trend outweigh disadvantages?

  
  
**Answer:**  
It is true that the government does lack the construction policy to manage the building activities intensively to erect the brand-new flats and high-end workspaces in the cities at the moment. While I understand that critics may see this as a considerable contribution into the national architectural flourish, I strongly believe that the disadvantages do outweigh the advantages.  
  
There are two main reasons why people might approve of uncontrollably raising new constructions in metropolitans. The first objection is that the massively estate-design syntonisation eliminates the main function of the architectural industry in human life. The industry clearly lasts along with the human's history and contributes largely into general achievements and developments of our species of humanity. The second argument supporting the freedom of constructing distinguished houses in the urban areas is that citizens spend their golden efforts and valuable youth in order to earn money and to possess their own properties. As a result, they are obviously able to build the house based on any personal design in their own desires in the sense of basic human rights.  
  
In spite of the benefits mentioned above, I truly believe that the promulgation and administration of the liberal terms in the construction law to the estate-raising activities in towns is a negative measure. They key point in this issue is that negatively huge impacts of uncontrolled building activities will bring constructions an existence, which are fundamentally not guaranteed in terms of safety and hygienic conditions. For instance, the landlord or the owners of business premises would always prefer to invade the pavement, and it's not only in the land base but it's also in the upper space in order to take advantage of the extra area of land. As a result, people, who stroll on the sidewalk, definitely take risks of accidents due to the collapse of the long and large balcony above. By contrast, due to the baby-boomer era of Vietnam at the moment, massive demand of housing increases rapidly in the recent background of the policies and standards, and the risky flats and houses, which are just pieces of tiny space without any inner fire fighting and prevention system, will surely endanger the lives of local residents as the visible result.  
  
In conclusion, it seems to me that we lose more than we gain from the self-monitored infrastructure that the uncontrolled constructions bring to our cities.

It is undeniable that the importance of creating an appealing image has significantly increased in contemporary society. This trend can be observed in various aspects of our lives, from personal branding on social media to political campaigns and advertisements. However, whether this emphasis on surface-level appearances has surpassed the value of truth and reality is a contentious issue. In this essay, I will argue that while creating an attractive image is crucial for success in many contexts, it should not override the importance of authenticity and substance.

To begin with, the proliferation of social media platforms has made personal branding an essential aspect of contemporary life. Individuals now have the power to craft and present themselves however they choose, creating a carefully curated image that they hope will attract attention, influence others, and advance their career or business interests. In this context, creating an appealing image becomes a necessity for success. For instance, actors and models must maintain a certain public image to secure roles and endorsements, while influencers must cultivate a relatable yet aspirational online presence to maintain their followings.

On the other hand, the pursuit of image over substance can lead to the distortion of reality and the spread of misinformation. For instance, during political campaigns, candidates often engage in image manipulation to craft a favorable public image, using catchy slogans, well-rehearsed soundbites, and slick advertisements to mask their true intentions or track records. This obsession with creating a positive image can result in voters making ill-informed decisions based on superficial appeals rather than substantive policy differences. A notable example of this is the election of former U.S. President Donald Trump, whose campaign was marked by controversial statements and divisive rhetoric but was nevertheless successful in projecting an image of strength and decisiveness that appealed to many voters.

Additionally, the importance placed on image can lead to unrealistic expectations and harmful body image issues. The beauty and fashion industries, in particular, have long perpetuated unattainable standards of beauty and perfection through the use of airbrushing, photo editing software, and the promotion of unrealistic body types. This has contributed to the development of eating disorders, body dysmorphia, and other mental health issues among individuals, particularly women and children, who feel pressured to conform to these unrealistic ideals.

In conclusion, while creating an appealing image is undeniably important in contemporary society, it should not supersede the importance of truth and reality. Authenticity and substance are vital for maintaining trust and credibility, particularly in areas such as politics and public service, where leaders are expected to deliver on their promises. Furthermore, the pursuit of image at the expense of reality can have serious consequences, including the spread of misinformation, the development of unhealthy body image issues, and the erosion of public trust. Therefore, while it is essential to present oneself in the best possible light, it is equally important to remain grounded in reality and to prioritize authenticity and substance.
